{"uri": "2024-05-350025871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:35:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:35:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:19:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/why-israel-competing-eurovision-song-091936325.html", "title": "Why is Israel competing in the Eurovision Song Contest 2024?", "body": "Israel will compete in this year's Eurovision Song Contest, despite calls for the country to be banned from participating due to its ongoing war on Gaza.\n\nEden Golan is representing Israel with the track \"Hurricane\", which was reworked from original entry \"October Rain\" after it was alleged to include references to the 7 October attacks by Hamas, therefore breaching the European Broadcasting Union's (EBU) rules over political songs.\n\nThe Israel-born Golan, who grew up in Russia, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nShe is due to compete in the second semi-final on Thursday 9 May, where she will be up against favourites including Switzerland's Nemo with \"The Code\", and the Netherlands' Joost with \"Europapa\".\n\nProtests over Israel's participation are underway in Malm\u00f6, Sweden, which is hosting this year's contest following Swedish contestant Loreen's win with \"Tattoo\" in 2023.\n\nWhy is Israel competing in Eurovision?\n\nNon-European countries are still allowed to take part in Eurovision if they become a member of the EBU, the organiser behind the event.\n\nThis means that countries such as Israel, Azerbaijan, Georgia and Australia are allowed to compete.\n\nThe EBU has defended its decision to permit Israel to take part and rejected comparisons to Russia, which was banned from participating in 2022 due to consistent breaches of membership obligations and a violation of \"public service media values\".\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) which organises Eurovision, said it based its decision to include Kan on the competition rules in place.\n\n\"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values,\" he said. \"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHas Israel won Eurovision before?\n\nIsrael has won Eurovision four times, first in 1978 with Izhar Cohen and the Alphabeta's \"A-Ba-Ni-Bi\", then again the following year with Milk and Honey singing \"Hallelujah\".\n\nIts next triumph was in 1998, in a historic moment where Dana International became the first transgender artist to win the Eurovision Song Contest with her song \"Diva\", turning her into a global icon.\n\nIsrael's most recent win was with Netta, who performed the eccentric pop song \"Toy\", in 2018.\n\nWho has been calling for a boycott?\n\nIn April, the collective Queers for Palestine circulated an open letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake, calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to withdraw from Eurovision 2024 in protest against Israel's participation.\n\nArtists and music organisations in Finland, Sweden, Ireland and Iceland have also protested against their countries' delegates taking part.\n\nMeanwhile, protests have taken place in Sweden as well as outside the BBC's Broadcasting House in London, and in Barcelona, Amsterdam and Reykjavik.\n\nHow have Eurovision artists responded?\n\nAlexander and other Eurovision artists shared a statement in response to the Queers for Palestine letter, beginning by acknowledging the \"privilege of taking part in Eurovision\".\n\n\"In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent.\n\n\"It is important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages. We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and islamophobia.\"\n\nHis team continued with a message of optimism and a belief in the \"power of music\", adding: \"We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n\"We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.\"\n\nThe decision has led to online backlash with Queers For Palestine who organised the original letter, calling the statement \"condescending\" and accusing Alexander of a \"lack of concern, if not contempt for the Palestinian people of Gaza\".\n\nAlexander's response was branded \"disappointing\" by critics, with many on social media pointing to his history of activism and accusing him of hypocrisy.\n\nHowever, some Eurovision participants have continued to be vocal in their calls for a ceasefire in Gaza, pushing back against the EBU's requests to keep the contest a \"non-political\" event.\n\nSwedish pop singer Eric Saade wore the Middle Eastern scarf around his wrist during a guest performance at the first semi-final of the contest in Malm\u00f6, Sweden, on Tuesday evening (7 May). The scarf has continually been used as a symbol of pro-Palestine support throughout Israel's ongoing war in Gaza.\n\nSaade's decision to wear the scarf was condemned by the EBU, who announced ahead of the competition that they reserve the right to remove any Palestinian flags and pro-Palestine symbols at the show.\n\nIreland's Bambie Thug told a press conference in Malm\u00f6 that they were forced to change their body paint in Ogham script (an early Medieval alphabet), which translated to \"ceasefire\" and \"freedom\", a nod to the situation in Gaza and amid Israel's inclusion in the competition.\n\n\"It was very important for me because I'm pro justice and pro peace,\" Bambie said. \"Unfortunately, I had to change those messages today to 'crown the witch' only (which was an) order from the EBU.\"\n\nA spokeswoman for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) said: \"The writing seen on Bambie Thug's body during dress rehearsals contravened contest rules that are designed to protect the non-political nature of the event.\n\n\"After discussions with the Irish delegation, they agreed to change the text for the live show.\"\n\nWhat has the EBU said about the protests?\n\nIn April, the EBU issued its own statement condemning \"abuse or harassment\" directed at participants.\n\n\"The EBU recognises the strong emotions stirred by this year's Eurovision Song Contest and the intense debate sparked by the inclusion of an Israeli entry,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We would like to stress that any decisions regarding participation are the responsibility of the EBU's governing bodies, not the individual artists. We are firmly against any form of abuse or harassment directed at participants, online or offline, and are committed to fostering a safe, respectful, and inclusive environment.\n\n\"We advocate for constructive dialogue and support for the artists, underlining the Contest's mission to be United by Music.\"", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, {"uri": "8118997915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:03:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:03:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:02:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13399707/Police-arrive-Malmo-s-main-square-Eurovision-protests.html", "title": "Police arrive at Malmo\u00b4s main square before Eurovision protests", "body": "A heavy police presence has arrived at Malmo's main square ahead of protests against Israel's inclusion in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nOfficers in more than five vans arrived in Stortorget ahead of Eden Golan, representing Israel, taking to the stage on Thursday evening in Malmo Arena.\n\nThe Swedish Police Authority positioned themselves at various entrance points to the square as tourists walked around taking pictures of the fountain and the town hall.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place in the afternoon, which a spokesman for the force said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nThe organisers of the march say the demonstration will take place at 3pm, with it ending at Molleplatsen park.\n\nOfficers from Sweden, along with Norway and Denmark, have been regularly patrolling Malmo Arena, the city centre and the Eurovision village amid Israel facing calls to be excluded from the contest because of the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Gaza Health Ministry, run by the proscribed terrorist organisation Hamas, puts the Palestinian death toll at more than 34,000 people.\n\nGolan's emotional Hurricane was reworked from a previous track called October Rain, which was thought to reference the Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nGolan, 20, will compete against Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, who called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying that they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been singing and dancing on stage since she was a child, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nJoost Klein of the Netherlands performs the song Europapa (Martin Meissner/AP)\n\nOrganisers of Eurovision, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), hit out in April against the \"unacceptable and totally unfair\" abuse of competitors amid \"the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East\".\n\nThe group, whose members approved Israeli broadcaster Kan, has taken a strong stance, as in previous years, against political messages at Eurovision and flags and symbols from non-competing countries.\n\nDespite the position, Tuesday's first semi-final saw former Swedish contestant and opening act Eric Saade wear a keffiyeh pattern material, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that he \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\" and it \"regrets\" the broadcast.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Saade said that the material was a \"way of showing a part of my origin\" and was a gift as a child from his father, who is of Palestinian origin.\n\nHe also said: \"I just wanted to be inclusive and wear something that is authentic to me - but the EBU seems to think my ethnicity is controversial.\n\n\"It says nothing about me, but everything about them.\"\n\nIt also told Irish finalist Bambie Thug to change their body paint, which referenced the artist's call for a ceasefire, before going on stage as the EBU maintains this could have broken the rules that are \"designed to protect the non-political nature of the event\".\n\nA man holds a Palestinian flag as he protests ahead of the first semi-final at the Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden (Martin Meissner/AP)\n\nIsrael, which performs towards the end of the night, has been a strong contender at Eurovision in recent years, last winning with Netta's Toy in 2018 and qualifying for the final 12 times since 2003.\n\nIt has won a total of four times, and will face tough competition this year from Switzerland's Nemo, whose operatic-pop music The Code has been seen as one of the favourites to win on Saturday.\n\nThe rehearsals have already shown Golan back bending in a white dress before emerging in a circle flanked by dancers as well as being bathed with yellow light as the song reaches its crescendo.\n\nThere were shouts at the rehearsals on Wednesday, which reportedly included boos and people saying \"free Palestine\".\n\nNetherlands act Joost Klein, with the irreverent and silly Europapa, and Norway's Gate with folkish Ulveham are also seen as likely to progress to the final.\n\nFrance's Slimane with the soulful Mon Amour will also perform on Thursday, alongside Italy's Angelina Mango with La Noia and Spain's Nebulossa with Zorra, but is already through to the final as one of the big EBU donators alongside the UK with Olly Alexander and Germany with Isaak.\n\nThe 2024 hosts of Eurovision are Swedish comedian Petra Mede and Hollywood actress Malin Akerman.\n\nBBC One and BBC iPlayer begin the broadcast of the second semi-final from 8pm on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", There was a large police presence, with a hovering helicopter, and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It's not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war, which has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians, has brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malmo. Music fans in colorful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in keffiyeh scarves.\n\nPalestinian flags fly from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nProtestors takes part in the Stop Israel demonstration between Stortorget and M\u00f6lleplatsen in Malm\u00f6, Sweden, Thursday, May 9, 2024. There have been calls for Israel to be excluded from the Eurovision Song contest because of its conduct in its war against Hamas. (Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency via AP)\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malmo during the contest.\n\nContest organizers, who try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas.\n\nBut they told Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, originally titled \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' cross-border Oct. 7 attack that killed some 1,200 Israelis and triggered the war. The song was renamed \"Hurricane\" and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest.\n\nShe will compete in Thursday's semi-final. Some audience members attending a dress rehearsal on Wednesday could be heard to boo during Golan's performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government's crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We're supposed to be united by music but we're not united, because Israel is participating,\" said Malmo resident Anders Trolle-Schultz, who attended the protest.\n\n\"I think Malmo should have kept Eurovision, but we should have told Israel either 'Stay away,' or maybe even say, why don't we invite a Palestinian music group to participate? She is not only an exceptional performer, but a symbol of strength and resilience. We \u2764\ufe0f you Eden and our entire country is cheering you on.\"\n\nLast month, the European Broadcasting Union, which organizes the competition, released a statement condemning harassment and attacks against Golan on social media.\n\nYet, Israel's National Security Council raised the travel alert level for Malmo and advised Israelis not to attend Eurovision, calling the Swedish city \"an anti-Israel protest hub\" with \"often violent\" demonstrations.\n\n\"These developments raise credible concerns that terrorist factions will take advantage of the demonstrations and the anti-Israel atmosphere to execute attacks on Israelis coming to Sweden for the Eurovision,\" the National Security Council warned.\n\nMORE: By the Numbers: Eurovision song contest\n\nThe popular European show drew in an audience of 216 million people last year, according to the European Broadcasting Union, almost twice as many as this year's Super Bowl.\n\nThe EBU reportedly refused Israel's entry to the competition twice, saying the lyrics to songs it had chosen were too political, according to Euronews.\n\nA submission from Golan called \"October Rain\" was objected to by the EBU because the title and some of the songs were overtly political, according to The New York Times. She edited the lyrics and renamed the song, \"Hurricane.\"\n\nIn a statement earlier this year, the EBU defended the decision to allow Israel to participate, despite the ongoing conflict.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a non-political music event and a competition between public service broadcasters who are members of the EBU. It is not a contest between governments,\" EBU Director General Noel Curran said in a Jan. 31 statement.\n\n\"As a member-led organization, our governing bodies -- the Eurovision Song Contest Reference Group and the Executive Board -- did review the participants list for the 2024 Contest and agreed that the Israeli public broadcaster KAN met all the competition rules for this year and can participate as it has for the past 50 years,\" Curran said.\n\nMORE: Destruction in Gaza: Side-by-side aerial look at the Israel-Hamas war's devastating damage\n\nFacing backlash over the move in light of Russia being excluded in 2022 after the invasion of Ukraine, Curran said the relationship between Israeli broadcaster KAN and the Israeli government is \"fundamentally different to the relationship that exists between those Russian Members and the State.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the many voices calling to exclude Israel from this year's competition in the same way as we excluded the Russian broadcaster in 2022 following the invasion of Ukraine,\" Curran said. \"Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and, as a non-political media organization, not ours to make. In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.\"\n\nIsrael launched an incursion into the Gaza Strip following an unprecedented terrorist attack by Hamas on Oct. 7 that killed about 1,200 people, according to the Israeli government. Israel's military operation has killed nearly 35,000 people in Gaza, according to the Hamas-run health ministry.\n\nSixteen countries will compete in Thursday's semifinals, including Israel, with 10 moving on to the finals on Saturday. The winners are determined by a jury of music professionals and a public vote.\n\nIsrael has won the competition -- which started in 1956 -- four times, most recently in 2018.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8119638784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:41:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:41:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:41:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/palestinian-eurovision-protest-1.7199098", "title": "Pro-Palestinian demonstrators protest Israel's Eurovision inclusion | CBC News", "body": "Not everyone in Malm\u00f6 was welcoming the Eurovision Song Contest to town.\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators protested in the Swedish port city on Thursday against Israel's participation in the pan-continental pop competition.\n\nProtesters waving green, white, black and red Palestinian flags packed the historic Stortorget square near Malm\u00f6's 16th-century town hall before a planned march through the city for a rally in a park several kilometres from the Eurovision venue.\n\nPolice estimated that between 10,000 and 12,000 people took part. Among those in the crowd was Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg.\n\nChanting \"from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free\" and \"Israel is a terror state,\" the demonstrators set off smoke flares in the Palestinian colours during a noisy, peaceful rally to criticize Israel and call for a ceasefire in Gaza. There was a large police presence, with a hovering helicopter, and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malm\u00f6 resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It's not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nProtester Saadallah Aoudi, a Swedish citizen with Palestinian roots, said \"this is the wrong time\" for Israel to take part in the competition: \"It's about songs, and songs are about love.... They should be here when there is peace.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war, which has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's health ministry, has brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malm\u00f6. Music fans in colourful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in keffiyeh scarves. Palestinian flags are flying from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nA smaller pro-Israel protest was also held Thursday in a central Malm\u00f6 square.\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" that Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malm\u00f6 during the contest.\n\nContest organizers, who try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas. But they told Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, originally titled October Rain in apparent reference to the Hamas-led cross-border Oct. 7 attack that killed some 1,200 people, according to Israeli officials.\n\nThe song was renamed Hurricane, with some of its lyrics changed, and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest. She will compete in Thursday's semifinal. Some audience members attending a dress rehearsal on Wednesday could be heard booing during Golan's performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government's crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We're supposed to be united by music, but we're not united, because Israel is participating,\" said Malm\u00f6 resident Anders Trolle-Schultz, who attended the protest. \"I think Malm\u00f6 should have kept Eurovision, but we should have told Israel, either 'Stay away,' or maybe even say, why don't we invite a Palestinian music group to participate? That would be fair.\"\n\nHistorian Dean Vuletic, author of Postwar Europe and the Eurovision Song Contest, said Eurovision has long been a focus of political controversies. Turkey's 1974 invasion of Cyprus led to a Greek boycott the following year. Georgia pulled out of Eurovision in 2009, a year after it fought a brief war with Russia, when organizers rejected its proposed song, We Don't Wanna Put In -- an obvious reference to Russian leader Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"Whenever countries compete with each other, things are going to get political,\" and Eurovision has always reflected the \"political zeitgeist\" in Europe, he said. While the last two years' competitions have seen an outpouring of support for Ukraine, this year \"we see Europe divided over the war in Gaza.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8119322840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:37:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:37:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:36:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/eurovision-2024-israels-entry-draws-142518662.html", "title": "Eurovision 2024: Israel's entry draws pro-Palestine protest in Malmo's main square", "body": "Pro-Palestine protesters gathered at Malmo's main square ahead of Israel's performance in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest on Thursday.\n\nSome chanted \"Free, Free Palestine\" and slogans about Rafah, with Palestinian flags and placards on display. Some called for Israel to be disqualified from the contest.\n\nClimate activist Greta Thunberg, 21, was among the protesters.\n\nA pro-Israel demonstration is expected later.\n\nSwedish officers in more than five vans arrived in Stortorget ahead of Eden Golan, representing Israel, taking to the stage on Thursday evening in Malmo Arena.\n\nThe Swedish Police Authority positioned themselves at various entrance points to the square as tourists walked around taking pictures of the fountain and the town hall.\n\nOfficers from Sweden, along with Norway and Denmark, have been regularly patrolling Malmo Arena, the city centre and the Eurovision village amid Israel facing calls to be excluded from the contest because of the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Gaza Health Ministry, run by the proscribed terrorist organisation Hamas, puts the Palestinian death toll at more than 34,000 people.\n\nGolan's emotional Hurricane was reworked from a previous track called October Rain, which was thought to reference the Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nGolan, 20, will compete against Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, who called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying that they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been singing and dancing on stage since she was a child, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nOrganisers of Eurovision, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), hit out in April against the \"unacceptable and totally unfair\" abuse of competitors amid \"the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East\".\n\nThe group, whose members approved Israeli broadcaster Kan, has taken a strong stance, as in previous years, against political messages at Eurovision and flags and symbols from non-competing countries.\n\nDespite the position, Tuesday's first semi-final saw former Swedish contestant and opening act Eric Saade wear a keffiyeh pattern material, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that he \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\" and it \"regrets\" the broadcast.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Saade said that the material was a \"way of showing a part of my origin\" and was a gift as a child from his father, who is of Palestinian origin.\n\nHe also said: \"I just wanted to be inclusive and wear something that is authentic to me - but the EBU seems to think my ethnicity is controversial.\n\n\"It says nothing about me, but everything about them.\"\n\nIt also told Irish finalist Bambie Thug to change their body paint, which referenced the artist's call for a ceasefire, before going on stage as the EBU maintains this could have broken the rules that are \"designed to protect the non-political nature of the event\".\n\nIsrael, which performs towards the end of the night, has been a strong contender at Eurovision in recent years, last winning with Netta's Toy in 2018 and qualifying for the final 12 times since 2003.\n\nIt has won a total of four times, and will face tough competition this year from Switzerland's Nemo, whose operatic-pop music The Code has been seen as one of the favourites to win on Saturday.\n\nThe rehearsals have already shown Golan back bending in a white dress before emerging in a circle flanked by dancers as well as being bathed with yellow light as the song reaches its crescendo.\n\nThere were shouts at the rehearsals on Wednesday, which reportedly included boos and people saying \"free Palestine\".\n\nNetherlands act Joost Klein, with the irreverent and silly Europapa, and Norway's Gate with folkish Ulveham are also seen as likely to progress to the final.\n\nFrance's Slimane with the soulful Mon Amour will also perform on Thursday, alongside Italy's Angelina Mango with La Noia and Spain's Nebulossa with Zorra, but is already through to the final as one of the big EBU donators alongside the UK with Olly Alexander and Germany with Isaak.\n\nThe 2024 hosts of Eurovision are Swedish comedian Petra Mede and Hollywood actress Malin Akerman.", "source": {"uri": There was a large police presence, with a hovering helicopter, and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It\u00b4s important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It\u00b4s not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war, which has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians, has brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malmo. Music fans in colorful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in keffiyeh scarves.\n\nA protester shouts into a megaphone during a Pro-Palestinian demonstration for excluding Israel from Eurovision ahead of the second semi-final at the Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden, Thursday, May 9, 2024. (AP Photo/Martin Meissner)\n\nPalestinian flags fly from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael\u00b4s government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malmo during the contest.\n\nContest organizers, who try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas.\n\nBut they told Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, originally titled \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas\u00b4 cross-border Oct. 7 attack that killed some 1,200 Israelis and triggered the war. The song was renamed \"Hurricane\" and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest.\n\nShe will compete in Thursday\u00b4s semi-final. Some audience members attending a dress rehearsal on Wednesday could be heard to boo during Golan\u00b4s performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government\u00b4s crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We\u00b4re supposed to be united by music but we\u00b4re not united, because Israel is participating,\" said Malmo resident Anders Trolle-Schultz, who attended the protest.\n\n\"I think Malmo should have kept Eurovision, but we should have told Israel either 'Stay away,\u00b4 or maybe even say, why don\u00b4t we invite a Palestinian music group to participate? That would be fair.\"\n\nProtestors takes part in the Stop Israel demonstration between Stortorget and M\u00f6lleplatsen in Malm\u00f6, Sweden, Thursday, May 9, 2024. There have been calls for Israel to be excluded from the Eurovision Song contest because of its conduct in its war against Hamas. {"uri": "8119681508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:20:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:20:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:19:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2933863-eurovision-semi-final-kicks-off-with-focus-on-israeli-contestant", "title": "Eurovision semi-final kicks off with focus on Israeli contestant | Science-Environment", "body": "The second semi-final of the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest kicked off in Sweden late on Thursday, with much of the focus expected to be on Israel's performance after thousands joined a pro-Palestinian protest earlier in the day. Some 100,000 visitors have gathered in the southern Swedish city of Malmo for the annual kitsch-fest, which is taking place amid protests and boycotts over the Israeli military campaign in Gaza that was triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nEurovision fans dressed in quirky outfits, sequins and their national colours arrived for the event, while around a hundred protesters chanted \"boycott Israel\" and \"shame on you\" outside the venue before being ushered away by police. Climate activist Greta Thunberg earlier in the day joined more than 10,000 pro-Palestinian demonstrators in the centre of Malmo who object to Israel's participation in the musical contest.\n\nPolice said protests were largely calm. Nine people had been taken into custody and one person was arrested on suspicion of a serious crime against the Knife Act. Protester Eric Goran said in the past he would usually watch Eurovision, which is organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and has been held since 1956.\n\n\"This year I lost all respect for the EBU,\" he said. \"It's clear that they can't take a standpoint against what's going on. I think the only right thing to do is to boycott Israel.\" Swedish authorities have heightened security, bracing for possible unrest.\n\nMetal barricades and large concrete blocks have been put up around Malmo Arena, which is hosting the competition, and snipers were visible on buildings in the arena. Israeli contestant Eden Golan, 20, will perform her song \"Hurricane\". In a video statement, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised Golan for her participation.\n\n\"You are not only taking on Eurovision in a proud and very impressive manner, you are also contending successfully with an ugly wave of antisemitism - and representing the State of Israel with enormous honour,\" Netanyahu said. 'HYPOCRISY AND DOUBLE STANDARDS'\n\nProtester Amar, a Palestinian who declined to give his second name, said: \"I'm here today because I see the hypocrisy and double standards around the world.\" \"We are against what's happening in Gaza right now. But I also want people to understand that we don't hate Jews.\"\n\nA smaller pro-Israel demonstration was held later on Thursday, a few hundred metres from the pro-Palestinian protest, with attendants holding hands and dancing in a circle to old Israeli Eurovision hits. \"I'm here to defend Israel,\" said Rolf, 70, from the Swedish city of Lund, declining to give his second name.\n\n\"We are only a little group, but we want to be seen as well. I think it's a shame that this girl from Israel who is performing today has to stand against all this... She certainly feels the pressure.\" The EBU has resisted calls for Israel to be excluded but asked the country to modify the lyrics of its original song \"October Rain\", which appeared to reference the Hamas attack.\n\nGolan says she hopes her performance will help to unite people. \"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nThursday's semi-final will also feature contestants from Malta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, the Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Norway and the Netherlands.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", Among those in the crowd was the Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage, told AP. \"It's not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nProtester Saadallah Aoudi, a Swedish citizen with Palestinian roots, added that \"this is the wrong time\" for Israel to take part in the competition.\n\n\"It's about songs, and songs are about love. ... They should be here when there is peace,\" he said.\n\nA smaller pro-Israel protest was also held in a central Malmo square.\n\nPro-Palestinian groups say they plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's Eurovision entry, Eden Golan, was booed during a dress rehearsal on Wednesday. She was met with chants of \"Free Palestine\" and jeers by some members of the crowd.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has allowed Israel to enter this year's song contest, despite the country's ongoing attacks on Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian death toll is believed to have reached 34,000 people.\n\nGolan, 20, has told ITV News that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nAhead of the protests, BBC presenter Rylan came to the defence of Eurovision.\n\nSpeaking from Malm\u00f6, Rylan, who is hosting the BBC's coverage alongside Graham Norton and Scott Mills, told ITV's Good Morning Britain that the city is doing \"an amazing job of hosting\".\n\n\"The climate in the world at the minute isn't great and you know we're not silly to not understand that there's a lot going on in the world, but I think in the Eurovision bubble it's a song contest, it's all about the music and that's what we're here for,\" said the "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/police-arrive-at-malmos-main-square-before-eurovision-protests-1623451.html", "title": "Police arrive at Malmo's main square before Eurovision protests | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "By Charlotte McLaughlin, PA Senior Entertainment Reporter in Malmo, Sweden\n\nA heavy police presence has arrived at Malmo's main square ahead of protests against Israel's inclusion in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nOfficers in more than five vans arrived in Stortorget ahead of Eden Golan, representing Israel, taking to the stage on Thursday evening in Malmo Arena.\n\nThe Swedish Police Authority positioned themselves at various entrance points to the square as tourists walked around taking pictures of the fountain and the town hall.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place in the afternoon, which a spokesman for the force said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nThe organisers of the march say the demonstration will take place at 3pm, with it ending at Molleplatsen park.\n\nOfficers from Sweden, along with Norway and Denmark, have been regularly patrolling Malmo Arena, the city centre and the Eurovision village amid Israel facing calls to be excluded from the contest because of the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Gaza Health Ministry, run by the proscribed terrorist organisation Hamas, puts the Palestinian death toll at more than 34,000 people.\n\nGolan's emotional Hurricane was reworked from a previous track called October Rain, which was thought to reference the Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nGolan, 20, will compete against Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, who called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying that they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been singing and dancing on stage since she was a child, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nOrganisers of Eurovision, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), hit out in April against the \"unacceptable and totally unfair\" abuse of competitors amid \"the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East\".\n\nThe group, whose members approved Israeli broadcaster Kan, has taken a strong stance, as in previous years, against political messages at Eurovision and flags and symbols from non-competing countries.\n\nDespite the position, Tuesday's first semi-final saw former Swedish contestant and opening act Eric Saade wear a keffiyeh pattern material, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that he \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\" and it \"regrets\" the broadcast.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Saade said that the material was a \"way of showing a part of my origin\" and was a gift as a child from his father, who is of Palestinian origin.\n\nHe also said: \"I just wanted to be inclusive and wear something that is authentic to me - but the EBU seems to think my ethnicity is controversial.\n\n\"It says nothing about me, but everything about them.\"\n\nIt also told Irish finalist Bambie Thug to change their body paint, which referenced the artist's call for a ceasefire, before going on stage as the EBU maintains this could have broken the rules that are \"designed to protect the non-political nature of the event\".\n\nIsrael, which performs towards the end of the night, has been a strong contender at Eurovision in recent years, last winning with Netta's Toy in 2018 and qualifying for the final 12 times since 2003.\n\nIt has won a total of four times, and will face tough competition this year from Switzerland's Nemo, whose operatic-pop music The Code has been seen as one of the favourites to win on Saturday.\n\nThe rehearsals have already shown Golan back bending in a white dress before emerging in a circle flanked by dancers as well as being bathed with yellow light as the song reaches its crescendo.\n\nThere were shouts at the rehearsals on Wednesday, which reportedly included boos and people saying \"free Palestine\".\n\nNetherlands act Joost Klein, with the irreverent and silly Europapa, and Norway's Gate with folkish Ulveham are also seen as likely to progress to the final.\n\nFrance's Slimane with the soulful Mon Amour will also perform on Thursday, alongside Italy's Angelina Mango with La Noia and Spain's Nebulossa with Zorra, but is already through to the final as one of the big EBU donators alongside the UK with Olly Alexander and Germany with Isaak.\n\nThe 2024 hosts of Eurovision are Swedish comedian Petra Mede and Hollywood actress Malin Akerman.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking {"uri": "8119106283", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:12:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:12:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:11:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/eurovision-2024-why-people-boycotting-120605792.html", "title": "Eurovision 2024: Why and how some people are boycotting the contest as Israel set to participate", "body": "Israel's entry for the Eurovision Song Contest, Eden Golan, is set to make her first appearance in the 2024 competition at the semi-final on Thursday (May 9).\n\nThe 20-year-old is one of 16 competing for 10 places in the final on Saturday, although her appearance has always been about more than the music.\n\nCampaigners have called for a boycott of the annual singing competition over Israel's inclusion in the contest amid the ongoing conflict in Gaza.\n\nGolan has already changed the lyrics of her song - with her original choice October Rain deemed to be too political in its reference to the country's campaign against Palestine.\n\nThe reworked track, now called Hurricane, complies with the regulations of Eurovision's parent organisation, the European Broadcasting Union.\n\nBut the problems have not stopped there and Israel's inclusion has attracted protests which will likely continue if Golan makes the final on Saturday.\n\nHowever, the singer is determined to compete with the aim of bringing a fifth Eurovision crown home to Jerusalem.\n\nSpeaking to ITV News' arts editor Nina Nannar, she said: \"People can say whatever they want, they have a right to speak their minds, speak their heart.\n\n\"I'm focusing on my mission and on the good and on the fact we're united here by music.\"\n\nShe added: \"I'm showing our voice. It's a huge amount of power and honour I have to be the voice of millions of people and show that we're here and be the voice of people who are not home right now and we need to bring home.\"\n\nThe Hamas-Israel conflict has led to over 34,000 Palestinians being killed since fighting began in October.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place on Thursday, which the Swedish Police Authority said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nHowever, Israel - which has been competing since joining the EBU in 1973 - is set to take part in the contest. The country has previously won in 1978, 1979, 1998 and 2018.\n\nAhead of the event at Malmo Arena, fans have been warned not to bring Palestinian flags, symbols or bags and have been told that there will be \"vigorous security checks\".\n\nThe terrorist threat level is on four points out of five, but the Swedish Police Authority has said that this is not related to the contest.\n\nFollowing the outbreak, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nFinnish, Swedish, Irish and Icelandic musical artists have also called for Israel to be prevented from competing and for their acts to not go along to the contest.\n\nOn April 25, protests were held outside the BBC's Broadcasting House in London by the LGTBQ+ solidarity group Queers For Palestine. Similar demonstrations were also held in Barcelona, Amsterdam and Reykjavik.\n\nHowever, Eurovision host Rylan Clark has defended the Eurovision Song Contest ahead of further protests over Israel's participation.\n\nYears and Years singer Alexander, Irish entrant Bambie Thug along with Norway's Gate, Portugal's Iolanda, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo, Lithuanian singer Silvester Belt and Finland's Windows95Man/Teemu Keisteri have all rejected calls to boycott the contest.\n\nHowever, in a joint statement they did call for \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages\" and said they \"stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and Islamophobia\".\n\nOn Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the EBU said if you \"exclude Kan (Israeli public broadcaster) outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take\" as an apolitical member organisation.\n\nHe also said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\nThe EBU had come under fire for allowing Israel to compete at a time of war while also banning Russia from competing after it invaded Ukraine.Russia has not competed since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022 and nor has Belarus.\n\nThe Eurovision website states that \"Russian public service broadcasters had their EBU membership suspended in 2022 due to consistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service media values\".", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-350373638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:50:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:50:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:33:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2024-05-09/thousands-of-pro-palestinian-protesters-march-in-malmo-against-israels-eurovision-participation", "title": "Thousands of Pro-Palestinian Protesters March in Malmo Against Israel's Eurovision Participation", "body": "MALMO, Sweden (AP) -- Not everyone in Malmo was welcoming the Eurovision Song Contest to town.\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators protested in the Swedish port city on Thursday against Israel's participation in the pan-continental pop competition.\n\nProtesters waving green, white and red Palestinian flags packed the historic Stortorget square near Malmo's 16th-century town hall before a planned march through the city for a rally in a park several miles (kilometers) from the Eurovision venue.\n\nChanting \"from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free!\" and \"Israel is a terror state,\" the demonstrators set off smoke flares in the Palestinian colors during a noisy, peaceful rally to criticize Israel and call for a cease-fire. There was a large police presence, with a hovering helicopter, and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It's not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war, which has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians, has brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malmo. Music fans in colorful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in keffiyeh scarves.\n\nPalestinian flags fly from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malmo during the contest.\n\nContest organizers, who try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas.\n\nBut they told Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, originally titled \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' cross-border Oct. 7 attack that killed some 1,200 Israelis and triggered the war. The song was renamed \"Hurricane\" and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest.\n\nShe will compete in Thursday's semi-final. Some audience members attending a dress rehearsal on Wednesday could be heard to boo during Golan's performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government's crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We're supposed to be united by music but we're not united, because Israel is participating,\" said Malmo resident Anders Trolle-Schultz, who attended the protest.\n\n\"I think Malmo should have kept Eurovision, but we should have told Israel either 'Stay away,' or maybe even say, why don't we invite a Palestinian music group to participate? That would be fair.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8119042037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:32:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:32:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:30:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.cravenherald.co.uk/news/national/uk-today/24308444.eurovision-2024-semi-final-2-running-order/", "title": "What is the running order for the second semi-final of Eurovision 2024?", "body": "The first semi-final of the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest was held in Malmo, Sweden, on Tuesday (May 7) and saw the likes of Ireland, Finland and Croatia make it safely through to the final following a public vote.\n\nThey will join the 'Eurovision Big 5' - UK, Germany, Italy, France and Spain - in Saturday's (May 11) final which will air on BBC One and BBC iPlayer from 8pm.\n\nThe first Eurovision semi-final saw the likes of Silia Kapsis (Cyprus), Bambie Thug (Ireland) and Baby Lasagna (Croatia) take to the stage.\n\nIt also included performances from three countries who have already qualified for the final - the UK (Olly Alexander), Sweden (Marcus & Martinus) and Germany (ISAAK).\n\nTen countries were voted through to the Eurovision 2024 final during the first semi-final on Tuesday.\n\nThese 10 countries were:\n\nThe counties to miss out on a place in the final from semi-final 1 were:\n\nAnother 16 countries will battle it out on Thursday in the second semi-final for the final 10 spots in Saturday's Eurovision final in Malmo, Sweden.\n\nThe running order for the second semi-final of Eurovision 2024 is:\n\nFrance / Slimane - Mon amour (already qualified for the final)\n\nSpain / Nebulossa - ZORRA (already qualified for the final)\n\n13. Estonia / 5MIINUST x Puuluup - (nendest) narkootikumidest ei tea me (k\u00fcll) midagi\n\nItaly / Angelina Mango - La Noia (already qualified for the final)\n\nIsraeli Eurovision Song Contest entrant Eden Golan will perform her song Hurricane in the second semi-final despite calls for the country to be excluded from the event amid the ongoing war in Gaza.\n\nIsrael has faced calls to be excluded from Eurovision 2024 amid the war in the Gaza Strip, where the Health Ministry, run by the proscribed terrorist organisation Hamas, puts the Palestinian death toll at more than 34,000 people.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place on Thursday ahead of the second semi-final, which the Swedish Police Authority said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nEurovision host Rylan Clark has defended the decision to include Israel in Eurovision 2024 saying people have \"the right\" to protest but the song contest is \"just about the music.\"\n\nClark, who is hosting the BBC's coverage of the competition alongside Graham Norton and Scott Mills, told ITV's Good Morning Britain: \"Malmo is doing an amazing job of hosting Eurovision.\n\n\"The climate in the world at the minute isn't great and you know we're not silly to not understand that there's a lot going on in the world, but I think in the Eurovision bubble it's a song contest, it's all about the music and that's what we're here for.\n\n\"The city has done an amazing job, there's a lot of demonstrations happening and people have got the right to do that and but it's just about the music.\"\n\nMills added: \"It does feel a little different but it's about the music and the joy that we have every single year at Eurovision.\"\n\nRECOMMENDED READING:\n\nThe {"uri": "8119135123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:30:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:30:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:30:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.jta.org/2024/05/09/culture/eurovision-and-malmo-brace-for-protests-as-israeli-contestant-eden-golan-takes-the-stage", "title": "Eurovision and Malm\u00f6 brace for protests as Israeli contestant Eden Golan takes the stage - Jewish Telegraphic Agency", "body": "(JTA) -- As the 68th Eurovision Song Contest kicks into full gear, organizers who insist the event is \"non-political\" are fighting a crescendo of protests over Israel's participation amid the ongoing war in Gaza.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which organizes the global competition held in the Swedish city of Malm\u00f6 this year, has tirelessly pushed one slogan: \"United by Music.\" But the group's decision to keep Israel among 37 nations vying for a trophy has instead divided Malm\u00f6, triggered global petitions, caused artists to boycott and generated plans for a flood of street protests.\n\nEurovision launched with its first semifinal on Tuesday. Eden Golan, the 20-year-old singer representing Israel with her song \"Hurricane,\" drew both cheers and boos during a dress rehearsal on Wednesday in advance of the second semifinal on Thursday. Bookmakers have ranked Israel in the top 10 likely victors, which would land Golan among 26 contestants in the final on Saturday.\n\nLocals in Malm\u00f6, which has a longstanding reputation for antisemitism and a record of attacks on Jews by both neo-Nazis and members of the substantial Muslim immigrant minority, unsuccessfully petitioned the city to bar Israel from competing. (The last time the city hosted the contest, in 2013, Jews and non-Jews held a rally after Israeli fans reported harassment.)\n\nNow, Malm\u00f6 is brimming with Swedish police, along with reinforcements from Denmark and Norway, ahead of demonstrations against Israel's participation, including a boat march that took place on Wednesday. Police expect over 20,000 protesters in the small city's streets, outnumbering about 15,000 people holding tickets to gather in the Malm\u00f6 Arena. Outside of Malm\u00f6, Eurovision is expected to draw more than 150 million people to TV screens worldwide.\n\nParticipants hold up banners during a demonstration outside the City Hall in Malm\u00f6, Sweden on April 10, 2024 in connection with the municipal board's consideration of a citizens' proposal to stop Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest. (Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency/AFP via Getty Images)\n\nIsrael's inclusion in the contest sparked international backlash because of its deadly military campaign in Gaza. Over 160,000 people have signed a petition to ban Israel from Eurovision, while 20 artists dropped out from performing in events surrounding the contest. Some protest groups have organized alternative events in Malm\u00f6, such as \"FalastinVision,\" billed as a \"genocide-free song contest\" hosting 15 artists from eight countries -- including the Palestinian territories -- at a live show scheduled for the same time as Eurovision's final.\n\nAmong the artists performing at FalastinVision is Bashar Murad, a Palestinian singer who competed to represent Iceland in Eurovision this year and lost to Hera Bj\u00f6rk.\n\n\"Palestine is blocked from major events around the world -- including Eurovision -- so it's difficult for Palestinian artists to showcase our culture and art globally,\" Murad said in a statement to the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. \"FalastinVision is a beautiful way to address that.\"\n\nBoycotters have accused Eurovision of a double standard for including Israel after excluding Russia from its contest in 2022, one day after Russian troops invaded Ukraine. Noel Curran, head of the EBU, has maintained that Russia was cut off for failing to meet broadcaster guidelines that Israel has met.\n\n\"Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and, as a non-political media organization, not ours to make,\" Curran said in a statement. \"In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.\"\n\nAs part of Eurovision's \"non-political\" guidelines, the contest bars flags and signs other than the national flags of participants and the rainbow pride flag -- which means that Palestinian flags are not allowed in the venue.\n\nOn Tuesday, opening act performer Eric Saade -- a former Swedish contestant of Palestinian origin -- wore a keffiyeh on his wrist, a scarf seen as symbolizing Palestinian solidarity. Saade was reprimanded by the EBU, which said in a statement, \"We regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nEden Golan performs an emotional rendition of Aerosmith's \"I Don't Want to Miss a Thing,\" surrounded by empty chairs representing the missing hostages, for her grand finale performance to represent Israel in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest. (Screenshot via Mako.co.il)\n\nThe EBU also cited politicization concerns as its reason for rejecting Golan's initial song entry, titled \"October Rain.\" The song appeared to reference Hamas's Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, which killed about 1,200 people, took more than 250 hostage and triggered Israel's military assault in Gaza. Golan tweaked the song and renamed it \"Hurricane,\" although its lyrics could still be interpreted as a reaction to Oct. 7.\n\nFor many Israelis, the country's participation and success in the contest is a point of pride and an antidote to concerns -- heightened this year amid the war -- that Israel is isolated on the world stage. Israel was accepted into the contest in 1957, its second year, causing Egypt and Syria to exit. It competed for the first time in 1973 and has since won four times, most recently for \"Toy\" by Netta in 2018.\n\nGolan is largely staying out of view during Eurovision week for fear of security threats, skipping most events other than the live shows and rehearsals. In lieu of the contest's opening \"turquoise carpet\" event on Sunday, she went to a local ceremony marking Yom HaShoah, Holocaust Remembrance Day.\n\nFredrik Sieradzki, who heads the Jewish Learning Center in Malm\u00f6, said he welcomed Golan together with the Israeli delegation. Malm\u00f6 is home to a small Jewish community of about 1,000 people, including some parents who have complained of antisemitic incidents at their children's schools since Oct. 7, according to Sieradzki.\n\n\"Eden Golan lit one of the candles. We lit six candles and the seventh one, of course, for the latest victims,\" Sieradzki told JTA, referring to the people killed on Oct. 7. \"It was a very emotional get-together, we felt we were family. When Jews come here, we welcome them.\"\n\nIn an interview with Reuters, Golan avoided criticizing the protests against her performance.\n\n\"It's up to the people what to do,\" she said. \"They have the right to speak their voice, but I'm focusing on my part which is giving the best performance, and on the good, on the good vibes, the good people.\"", "source": {"uri": "jta.org", "dataType": show\n\nIsrael's Eurovision hopeful Eden has been told to only come out of her hotel room to perform over fears for her safety\n\nThe 20-year-old arrived in host city Malmo, in Sweden, on Tuesday afternoon for rehearsals and will reportedly be under round-the-clock bodyguard protection\n\nIsrael were told to change the lyrics of its song submission for this year's competition or risk being disqualified\n\nThis was later replaced by Hurricane, a soulful and heartfelt track that was then approved by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which runs the event.\n\nThe protest during her Eurovision protests", "body": "A HEAVY police presence has arrived at Malmo's main square ahead of planned protests against Israel's inclusion in this year's Eurovision.\n\nOfficers in more than five vans arrived in Stortorget ahead of Eden Golan, representing Israel, taking to the stage on Thursday night.\n\nThe Swedish Police Authority positioned themselves at various entrances to the square as tourists walked around taking pictures.\n\nGolan (above) was booed off the stage as the crowd chanted \"free Palestine\" during her performance in the Jury Show on Wednesday night.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place in the afternoon, which a spokesman for the force said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nThe organisers of the march say the demonstration will take place at 3pm, with it ending at Molleplatsen park.\n\nREAD MORE: Netanyahu is the main obstacle to peace and must be made to go\n\nOfficers from Sweden, along with Norway and Denmark, have been regularly patrolling Malmo Arena, the city centre and the Eurovision village amid Israel facing calls to be excluded from the contest because of the war in Gaza.\n\nGolan's song Hurricane was reworked from a previous track called October Rain, which was thought to reference the Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nGolan, 20, will compete against Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, who called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying that they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been singing and dancing on stage since she was a child, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nOrganisers of Eurovision, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), hit out in April against the \"unacceptable and totally unfair\" abuse of competitors amid \"the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East\".\n\nThe group, whose members approved Israeli broadcaster Kan, has taken a strong stance, as in previous years, against political messages at Eurovision and flags and symbols from non-competing countries.\n\nDespite the position, Tuesday's first semi-final saw former Swedish contestant and opening act Eric Saade wear a keffiyeh pattern material, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that he \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\" and it \"regrets\" the broadcast.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Saade said that the material was a \"way of showing a part of my origin\" and was a gift as a child from his father, who is of Palestinian origin.\n\nHe also said: \"I just wanted to be inclusive and wear something that is authentic to me - but the EBU seems to think my ethnicity is controversial.\n\n\"It says nothing about me, but everything about them.\"\n\nIt also told Irish finalist Bambie Thug to change their body paint, which referenced the artist's call for a ceasefire, {"uri": "8119170062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:55:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:55:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:54:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/05/09/police-arrive-at-malmos-main-square-before-eurovision-protests/", "title": "Police arrive at Malmo's main square before Eurovision protests | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Police arrive at Malmo's main square before Eurovision protests RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 9 May 2024, 1:16 PM Last updated: Thu 9 May 2024, 1:47 PM\n\nBy Charlotte McLaughlin, PA Senior Entertainment Reporter in Malmo, Sweden\n\nA heavy police presence has arrived at Malmo's main square ahead of protests against Israel's inclusion in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nOfficers in more than five vans arrived in Stortorget ahead of Eden Golan, representing Israel, taking to the stage on Thursday evening in Malmo Arena.\n\nThe Swedish Police Authority positioned themselves at various entrance points to the square as tourists walked around taking pictures of the fountain and the town hall.\n\nA pro-Palestinian march will take place in the afternoon, which a spokesman for the force said would cause \"disturbance to traffic\".\n\nThe organisers of the march say the demonstration will take place at 3pm, with it ending at Molleplatsen park.\n\nOfficers from Sweden, along with Norway and Denmark, have been regularly patrolling Malmo Arena, the city centre and the Eurovision village amid Israel facing calls to be excluded from the contest because of the war in Gaza.\n\nThe Gaza Health Ministry, run by the proscribed terrorist organisation Hamas, puts the Palestinian death toll at more than 34,000 people.\n\nGolan's emotional Hurricane was reworked from a previous track called October Rain, which was thought to reference the Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nThere have been continued demonstrations in Sweden over Israel's participation, and the week of Eurovision has already seen small gatherings in Malmo and at the Eurovision village when Austrian 2014 winner Conchita Wurst was on stage.\n\nGolan, 20, will compete against Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, who called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying that they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been singing and dancing on stage since she was a child, told ITV News this week that she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\".\n\nOrganisers of Eurovision, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), hit out in April against the \"unacceptable and totally unfair\" abuse of competitors amid \"the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East\".\n\nThe group, whose members approved Israeli broadcaster Kan, has taken a strong stance, as in previous years, against political messages at Eurovision and flags and symbols from non-competing countries.\n\nDespite the position, Tuesday's first semi-final saw former Swedish contestant and opening act Eric Saade wear a keffiyeh pattern material, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that he \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\" and it \"regrets\" the broadcast.\n\nIn an Instagram story, Saade said that the material was a \"way of showing a part of my origin\" and was a gift as a child from his father, who is of Palestinian origin.\n\nHe also said: \"I just wanted to be inclusive and wear something that is authentic to me - but the EBU seems to think my ethnicity is controversial.\n\n\"It says nothing about me, but everything about them.\"\n\nIt also told Irish finalist Bambie Thug to change their body paint, which referenced the artist's call for a ceasefire, before going on stage as the EBU maintains this could have broken the rules that are \"designed to protect the non-political nature of the event\".\n\nIsrael, which performs towards the end of the night, has been a strong contender at Eurovision in recent years, last winning with Netta's Toy in 2018 and qualifying for the final 12 times since 2003.\n\nIt has won a total of four times, and will face tough competition this year from Switzerland's Nemo, whose operatic-pop music The Code has been seen as one of the favourites to win on Saturday.\n\nThe rehearsals have already shown Golan back bending in a white dress before emerging in a circle flanked by dancers as well as being bathed with yellow light as the song reaches its crescendo.\n\nThere were shouts at the rehearsals on Wednesday, which reportedly included boos and people saying \"free Palestine\".\n\nNetherlands act Joost Klein, with the irreverent and silly Europapa, and Norway's Gate with folkish Ulveham are also seen as likely to progress to the final.\n\nFrance's Slimane with the soulful Mon Amour will also perform on Thursday, alongside Italy's Angelina Mango with La Noia and Spain's Nebulossa with Zorra, but is already through to the final as one of the big EBU donators alongside the UK with Olly Alexander and Germany with Isaak.\n\nThe 2024 hosts of Eurovision are Swedish comedian Petra Mede and Hollywood actress Malin Akerman.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 9 May 2024, 1:16 PM Last updated: Thu What Israel's Eurovision entry has said about Gaza conflict", "body": "Israel's Eurovision contestant was booed during a dress rehearsal on Wednesday ahead of her performance tonight in the second semi-final.\n\nEden Golan was performing her song \"Hurricane\" ahead of Thursday's semi-final in Malmo, Sweden. In response, she said she was \"proud to represent my country.\"\n\nIsrael has killed more than 34,000 Palestinians, including more than 14,000 children since October 7. The country is currently invading Rafah, the southern part of Gaza the Israeli government once labelled as a \"safe zone.\" The United Nations humanitarian aid agency warned last Friday this would put hundreds of thousands of people would be \"at imminent risk of death.\"\n\nThe war on Gaza has sparked widespread protests around the world, with more than 54,000 people signing an online petition calling for Israel to be banned from the competition. The refusal of the EBU to ban Israel, has left many fans calling for a boycott of the competition.\n\nSpeaking about allowing Israel to compete in the competition, the deputy director general of the EBU, Jean Philip De Tender, said banning the country would be a \"political decision.\" However, critics have been quick to point out how Russia were banned from the competition after it launched it war on Ukraine.\n\nEurovision organisers are expecting political protests in Malmo on Thursday and for Saturday's final.\n\nWho is Eden Golan?\n\nEden Golan, is a singer of Russian-Israeli descent and kickstarted her career by participating in the Russian selection for the Junior Eurovision Song Contest in 2015, followed by a stint on the Russian television show, The Voice Kids.\n\nLeading up to the Eurovision Song Contest in 2024, the Israeli Public Broadcasting Corporation opted to collaborate with the Keshet 12 channel and the talent show Rising Star to select the country's contestant.\n\nGolan emerged victorious through all phases of the competition, captivating audiences with renditions of Whitney Houston's \"I Have Nothing\" and Aerosmith's \"I Don't Want to Miss a Thing\" during the final.\n\nNow, she's making waves as Israel's representative in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest with controversial song \"Hurricane\".\n\nIt comes after her initial selection, originally submitted a song called \"October Rain\", which was widely thought to reference the Hamas attacks of 7 October after they included the lines: \"There's no air left to breathe\" and \"They were all good children, each one of them.\"\n\nThe EBU, confirmed it was \"scrutinising\" Israel's chosen song due to its lyrical content, before Israeli president Isaac Herzog intervened and called for \"necessary adjustments\" to ensure the country could take part in the competition and they updated the song - called \"Hurricane\".\n\nThe organisers have now said they will allow Israel to compete following the lyrics change.\n\nWhat has she said about the Israel-Gaza conflict?\n\nSpeaking to Reuters, Eden Golan she said: \"I come here to show my voice, to share my love, my gift from God and to hopefully make people feel something and leave a mark in their souls and to unite by music.\"\n\nAsked how she feels about the possibility of protests in Malmo, Golan added:\n\n\"It's up to the people what to do. They have the right to speak their voice, but I'm focusing on my part which is giving the best performance, and on the good, on the good vibes, the good people.\"\n\nGolan will now take to the stage
