{"uri": "8119667712", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:07:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:07:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:07:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/eurovision-2024-hit-by-protests-over-israel-taking-part-amid-gaza-war/", "title": "Eurovision 2024 hit by protests over Israel taking part amid Gaza war", "body": "Malmo, Sweden -- Not everyone was welcoming the Eurovision Song Contest to the Swedish city of Malmo. Thousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators protested in the Swedish port city Thursday against Israel's participation in the pan-continental pop competition. Protesters waving green, white and red Palestinian flags packed the historic Stortorget square near Malmo's 16th-century town hall before a planned march through the city for a rally in a park several miles from the Eurovision venue.\n\nChanting chanting and yelling slogans such as \"Israel is a terror state,\" the demonstrators set off smoke flares in the Palestinian colors during a noisy but peaceful rally to criticize Israel and call for a cease-fire in its war with Hamas.\n\nThe first of those slogans chanted by the protesters is a highly controversial reference to the creation of a Palestinian state, defined by the Anti-Defamation League as an \"antisemitic slogan commonly featured in anti-Israel campaigns and chanted at demonstrations.\"\n\nWhile many protesters reject the slogan being rooted in racism or calling for violence, the ADL says \"it is fundamentally a call for a Palestinian state extending from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean Sea, territory that includes the State of Israel, which would mean the dismantling of the Jewish state... It is an antisemitic charge denying the Jewish right to self-determination, including through the removal of Jews from their ancestral homeland.\"\n\nThere was a large police presence at the protest in Malmo on Thursday, with a helicopter hovering overhead and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It's not okay for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nOutrage over the ongoing Israel-Hamas brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malmo. Music fans in colorful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in traditional keffiyeh scarves.\n\nPalestinian flags fly from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" that Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malmo during the contest.\n\nOrganizers, who say they try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, with this year's them being unity through music, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas.\n\nThey did tell Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, however, which was originally titled \"October Rain,\" in an apparent reference to Hamas' cross-border Oct. 7 terrorist attack that killed some 1,200 Israelis and triggered the war. The song was renamed \"Hurricane,\" and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest.\n\nShe was to compete in a semi-final Thursday evening. Some audience members attending a Wednesday dress rehearsal could be heard to boo during Golan's performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government's crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We're supposed to be united by music but we're not united, because Israel is participating,\" said Malmo resident Anders Trolle-Schultz, who attended the protest.\n\n\"I think Malmo should have kept Eurovision, but we should have told Israel either 'Stay away,' or maybe even say, why don't we invite a Palestinian music group to participate? becoming a lightning rod for hate since the IDF invasion of Gaza after Hamas' sickening October 7 attacks.\n\nGolan has even been told by Israel's fearsome security service to stay in her hotel room, leaving only to perform, after receiving an avalanche of death threats and amid terror-attack fears.\n\nShe is not alone, though, and has received support from some of her nation's previous famous entrants.\n\nThe eyes of the world will be on Eden Golan for more than one reason when she takes to the stage in Malmo, Sweden, in the Eurovision final on Saturday\n\nGolan has been the target for pro-Palestine protesters who believe Israel should have been thrown out of this year's competition\n\nA Palestine flag is waved during Golan's performance of her song 'Hurricane' during the semi-final of the competition last night\n\nIsraeli Dana International, who was Eurovision's first transgender winner in 1998, told the LGBT community to condemn Hamas rather than Israel as she called to 'Free Palestine - from Hamas!'.\n\nRead More How Israel's Eurovision contestant has faced death threats and fears of a terror attack, but declares: 'I'm not worried - but I am prepared'\n\n'Things are far more complex than reciting some trend that sounds right to you,' she told her 114,000 followers on Instagram.\n\n'I ask you to open your eyes and hearts, and to see the truth, to see beyond any propaganda or a one-sided narrative as they shown on social media. Choose to see the side who sees you. Who shares the same values as you.'\n\nGali Atari, who was part of group Milk and Honey when Israel won in 1979, believes Golan would have a chance of winning if it was any other year.\n\n'And all the noise in the background makes it much more difficult,' she told The Jerusalem Post.\n\n'All this year, with the boos, the violent protests - it's all very frightening, but Eden handles it very well.'\n\nYet the tensions at this year's event are palpable.\n\nHeavily-armed police officers carrying machine guns are patrolling outside hotels, and drone-mounted cameras will monitor the crowds as they bid to keep the peace during the world's biggest pop competition.\n\nMost alarming of all, there are reports that terrorists are planning to bomb the arena.\n\nGolan shared a New York Times article on her Instagram page in which she defiantly says she 'won't let anything break me'\n\nFootage showed members of the crowd booing and shouting during Golan's performance on Wednesday night\n\nGolan pictured performing her song Hurricane during rehearsal at the Malmo Arena on Wednesday\n\nWithout question, Golan is Eurovision's most controversial entry this year and is said to be under constant bodyguard watch having faced death threats.\n\nIf there were any questions remaining about what kind of reception she will receive, those were resoundingly answered last night.\n\nAs she took to the stage dressed in a stone-coloured maxi dress that resembled bandages, boos filled the arena.\n\nRead More Moment Israeli singer Eden Golan's Eurovision performance is nearly drowned out by boos and chants of 'Free Palestine' in chaotic scenes\n\nGolan was nearly drowned out by the demonstrators chanting 'Free Palestine' while she performed 'Hurricane' during the Eurovision Song Contest's Jury Show.\n\nYet despite the threats on her life and fears of a terror attack, she has refused to be cowed and has remained steadfast in her response.\n\n'I won't let anything break me,' the Russian-Israeli defiantly says.\n\nBefore she flew out for this year's competition the young singer showed a composure that belied her years.\n\n'I wouldn't say I'm worried. I'm prepared,' she insisted to MailOnline, after some deliberation.\n\nBut her entry has been mired in controversy from the start. Denmark, Finland, Norway and even host country Sweden have repeatedly called for Israel to be banned from the contest altogether. And in Belgium, two Ministers demanded that the Jewish state be treated the same as Russia, which has been barred since 2022 following its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThat Eden's song has fallen foul of Eurovision rules stating that all entries must be strictly non-political, hasn't helped to ease the tension.\n\nSwedish protesters hold a placard calling for a boycott of Israel at a demonstration outside Malmo's City Hall against the country's participation in the Eurovision song contest\n\nA demonstrator displays a poster during a protest against Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest, ahead of the second semi-final, in Malmo, Sweden\n\nProtesters pull down a Eurovision flag during the 'Stop Israel' demonstration between Stortorget and Molleplatsen in Malmo\n\nThe original iteration of her piano-backed ballad Hurricane was called October Rain and was a barely disguised tribute to the victims of the Hamas terrorist attack last year. It included lyrics such as 'There's no air left to breathe' and 'They were all good children, each one of them'.\n\nRead More Israel's Eurovision contestant Eden Golan 'is told not to leave her room except for when she performs for her own safety' - as singer, 20, expresses her support for Israeli civilians held hostage by Hamas\n\n'I was going through a roller-coaster of emotions,' Golan says. 'The song itself has a powerful story.\n\n'When you're going through a lot within yourself and life in general...'\n\nWhile her family was not directly affected by the October 7 massacre, she has many friends who lost loved ones.\n\nOne friend's boyfriend was murdered at the Nova music festival, an event she finds too painful to discuss.\n\n'We can't disconnect from what's going on in our country,' she continues. 'The entire country is not going through an easy time. I feel like the horror of October 7 brought Jews closer, made us all united.'\n\nBut the original October Rain song was rejected by the contest's organisers, the European Broadcasting Union, on political grounds.\n\nAfter several revisions, October Rain was renamed as Hurricane and now tells the story of a woman emerging from a personal crisis.\n\nMusically, it's the same song but the lyrics are more generic, the references to the massacre replaced with phrases like 'every day, I'm losing my mind' and 'I'm still broken from this hurricane'.\n\nThe original iteration of Golan's piano-backed ballad Hurricane was called October Rain and was a barely disguised tribute to the victims of the Hamas terrorist attack last year\n\nGolan has become a lightning rod for hate since the invasion of Gaza in response to the Hamas atrocities of Ocober 7\n\nGolan has endured a barrage of death threats as Israel's entrant in the Eurovision Song Contest\n\nGolan is hoping the positive response to her music will outweigh any negativity.\n\n'People of all nationalities like the song,' she says confidently. 'They can disconnect from what they believe and just focus on the music.'\n\nBoth her parents hail from the former Soviet Union and while she was born in Kfar Saba, central Israel, they decided to move to Moscow when she was six.\n\nHer father Eddie, 56, is a businessman, while her mother, Olga, 50, is her manager - or 'momager'.\n\nWhile living in Moscow, she was educated at a British international school, where she got A-levels in maths, psychology and business.\n\nThe singer - who arrived in the city last week sporting a yellow pin, symbolising support for the release of hostages held by Hamas - insists that she is safe in Malmo despite the threats against her.\n\n'I'm getting a lot of love and support from my family and from the professional team that has become like a family.'\n\nShe added: 'Protests are of course not pleasant,but I can't wait to be there on stage and try to make people feel something in the three minutes that I have. {"uri": "8119673839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:13:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:13:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:12:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/International/israeli-contestant-draws-boos-controversy-eurovision-song-contest/story?id=110075019", "title": "Israeli contestant draws boos, controversy at Eurovision Song Contest", "body": "Protesters gathered to wave Palestinian flags and chanted \"boycott Israel.\"\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian protesters gathered in Sweden on Thursday to oppose the participation of an Israeli contestant in the semifinals of the massively popular Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nProtesters in Malmo, Sweden -- where the competition is being held after the country won the 2023 contest -- could be seen waving Palestinian flags and chanting \"boycott Israel.\" Later in the day, some Israeli supporters also came out to wave flags in support of the country's participation.\n\nControversy has surrounded the song \"Hurricane\" by 20-year-old Eden Golan, Israel's contestant, with many demanding she be excluded from the competition over Israel's war in Gaza.\n\nGolan also received boos during her dress rehearsal for the competition on Wednesday, according to the BBC.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, Israel's Foreign Ministry posted on X: \"We are incredibly proud of Eden Golan who is representing our country at @Eurovision. She is not only an exceptional performer, but a symbol of strength and resilience. We \u2764\ufe0f you Eden and our entire country is cheering you on.\"\n\nLast month, the European Broadcasting Union, which organizes the competition, released a statement condemning harassment and attacks against Golan on social media.\n\nThe popular European show drew in an audience of 216 million people last year, according to the European Broadcasting Union, almost twice as many as this year's Super Bowl.\n\nThe EBU reportedly refused Israel's entry to the competition twice, saying the lyrics to songs it had chosen were too political, according to Euronews.\n\nA submission from Golan called \"October Rain\" was objected to by the EBU because the title and some of the songs were overtly political, according to The New York Times. She edited the lyrics and renamed the song, \"Hurricane.\"\n\nIn a statement earlier this year, the EBU defended the decision to allow Israel to participate, despite the ongoing conflict.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a non-political music event and a competition between public service broadcasters who are members of the EBU. It is not a contest between governments,\" EBU Director General Noel Curran said in a Jan. 31 statement.\n\n\"As a member-led organization, our governing bodies -- the Eurovision Song Contest Reference Group and the Executive Board -- did review the participants list for the 2024 Contest and agreed that the Israeli public broadcaster KAN met all the competition rules for this year and can participate as it has for the past 50 years,\" Curran said.\n\nFacing backlash over the move in light of Russia being excluded in 2022 after the invasion of Ukraine, Curran said the relationship between Israeli broadcaster KAN and the Israeli government is \"fundamentally different to the relationship that exists between those Russian Members and the State.\"\n\n\"We are aware of the many voices calling to exclude Israel from this year's competition in the same way as we excluded the Russian broadcaster in 2022 following the invasion of Ukraine,\" Curran said. \"Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and, as a non-political media organization, not ours to make. In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.\"\n\nIsrael launched an incursion into the Gaza Strip following an unprecedented terrorist attack by Hamas on Oct. 7 that killed about 1,200 people, according to the Israeli government. Israel's military operation has killed nearly 35,000 people in Gaza, according to the Hamas-run health ministry.\n\nSixteen countries will compete in Thursday's semifinals, including Israel, with 10 moving on to the finals on Saturday. The winners are determined by a jury of music professionals and a public vote.\n\nIsrael has won the competition -- which started in 1956 -- four times, most recently in 2018.", "source": {"uri": I think it's just wrong.\"\n\nMore than 10,000 people gathered on Thursday afternoon in Malmo's main square before marching through the city's central pedestrian shopping street, according to police estimates.\n\nAlongside signs that read: \"Liberate Palestine\", banners that said \"EUR legitimises genocide\" and \"colonialism cannot be washed in pink\" could be seen in the crowd.\n\nAbout 50 protesters made it to the front of the Malmo Arena, where the event is taking place, before being dispersed by a heavy police presence. Protesters also entered the Eurovision Village, where spectators can follow the concert on large screens.\n\nIn a different neighbourhood, about 100 counter-protesters gathered under police protection to express their support for Israel.\n\nThe war in Gaza was sparked by Hamas' unprecedented October 7 attack on Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally of Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took about 250 hostages. Israel estimates 128 of them remain in Gaza, including 36 who officials say are dead.\n\nIsrael in response vowed to crush Hamas and launched a military offensive that has killed at least 34,904 people in Gaza, mostly women and children, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\n- 'Nothing to celebrate' -\n\nIn 2022, Russia's state broadcaster was excluded from the European Broadcasting Union, which oversees Eurovision, in the wake of the war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I feel like if they can remove Russia why can they not do it to Israel?\" said protester Marwo Mustafa.\n\n\"The people are here for Eurovision trying to celebrate. There's nothing to celebrate. It's an ongoing war,\" added 29-year-old Mustafa Mustafa.\n\nIsrael's entry, \"Hurricane\" by singer Eden Golan, will compete in Thursday's semi-final. It has already been partially re-written and given a new title after Eurovision organisers deemed the original version to be too political.\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Thursday wished Golan good luck and said she had \"already won\" by enduring the protests that he called a \"horrible wave of anti-Semitism\".\n\nSince the beginning of the year, several petitions have demanded Israel's exclusion from the 68th edition of the annual music competition.\n\nAt the end of March, contestants from nine countries, including Swiss favourite Nemo, called for a lasting ceasefire.\n\nProtester Cecilia Brudell told AFP: \"At six and nine, my children are now at an age where they want to watch Eurovision but this year we are completely boycotting it.\"", "source": {"uri": "8118984125", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:53:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:53:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:53:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/technology/2933183-factbox-eurovision-2024-what-to-expect-as-crowds-gather-amid-anti-israel-protests", "title": "FACTBOX-Eurovision 2024: what to expect, as crowds gather amid anti-Israel protests | Technology", "body": "The world's biggest live music event, the Eurovision Song Contest, is taking place in Sweden this week with 37 participating countries. Roughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nThe world's biggest live music event, the Eurovision Song Contest, is taking place in Sweden this week with 37 participating countries.\n\nRoughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza. WHEN IS THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2024?\n\nThe event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday. The Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nWHERE IS EUROVISION BEING HELD? The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985. The concert venue is the Malmo Arena, which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nWHAT DEMONSTRATIONS ARE EXPECTED? Several protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nProtests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT. A vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nWHO IS ISRAEL'S EUROVISION CONTESTANT? Eden Golan, 20, will represent Israel at this year's Eurovision with the song \"Hurricane\".\n\nIsrael was allowed to compete after agreeing to modify the lyrics of its original song \"October Rain\", which appeared to reference the Oct. 7 Hamas onslaught in Israel. Golan says she hopes her performance will help unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\" Israel has previously won Eurovision four times, in 1978, 1979, 1998 and 2018.\n\nWHAT SECURITY MEASURES HAVE BEEN TAKEN? Swedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high. Visitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed. HOW DOES VOTING WORK?\n\nThe results of the two semi-finals are decided by viewers, who can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or the Eurovision app. Viewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nThose in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain. In the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act. Each country will award points from 1 to 8, 10 and 12.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country. New to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior to each semi-final and the Grand Final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL? Croatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final. WHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands. WHO COMPETES IN THE GRAND FINAL?\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final. Last year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThere will be 26 acts in total in the final. WHY THE 'BIG FIVE'?\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). Since 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nHOW TO WATCH IT The song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nWHO IS THE FAVOURITE TO WIN EUROVISION? Bookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nWHO ARE THE PRESENTERS? The song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nEUROVISION HISTORY The Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia. Originally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television, with only seven countries competing - the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets. WHICH COUNTRIES HAVE WON THE MOST EUROVISIONS?\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019. WHO WON LAST YEAR?\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". There was a large police presence, with a hovering helicopter, and officers on rooftops with binoculars.\n\n\"It's important to be here,\" said Amani Eli-Ali, a Malmo resident of Palestinian heritage. \"It's not OK for Sweden to arrange this Eurovision and have Israel in the contest.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war, which has killed almost 35,000 Palestinians, has brought a jarring juxtaposition to Eurovision week in Malmo. Music fans in colorful sequined outfits or draped in their national flags mixed in the streets with supporters of the Palestinian cause in keffiyeh scarves.\n\nPalestinian flags fly from windows and balconies along a pedestrianized thoroughfare that has been temporarily renamed \"Eurovision street.\"\n\nPro-Palestinian groups plan to march again on Saturday, the day of the Eurovision final.\n\nIsrael's government warned its citizens of a \"tangible concern\" Israelis could be targeted for attack in Malmo during the contest.\n\nContest organizers, who try to keep Eurovision a non-political event, have rejected calls to bar Israel over the conduct of its war against Hamas.\n\nBut they told Israel to change the lyrics of its entry, originally titled \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' cross-border Oct. 7 attack that killed some 1,200 Israelis and triggered the war. The song was renamed \"Hurricane\" and Israeli singer Eden Golan was allowed to remain in the contest.\n\nShe will compete in Thursday's semi-final. Some audience members attending a dress rehearsal on Wednesday could be heard to boo during Golan's performance.\n\nCritics of the decision to let Israel compete point out that Russia was kicked out of Eurovision in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and Belarus was ejected a year earlier over its government's crackdown on dissent.\n\n\"We're supposed to be united by music but we're {"uri": "8119179497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:01:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:01:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:01:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/05/09/eurovision-said-israel-2024-song-contest-20799836/", "title": "What has Eurovision said about Israel being in the 2024 song contest?", "body": "Since it was announced Israel was competing in the Eurovision Song Contest 2024 there has been a huge backlash, with dedicated fans deciding to boycott the event.\n\nThe annual singing competition's organiser, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), even made a rare comment on the country's inclusion but refused to ban them as a 'non-political' body.\n\nDespite the EBU's stance, campaigners have repeatedly put pressure on the body to reverse its decision due to the ongoing conflict in Gaza, which has now claimed thousands of lives.\n\nIsrael's entry Eden Golan was forced to change the lyrics of her song October Rain, after it caused controversy as they were thought to reference the Hamas attacks on October 7.\n\nThe EBU's director general Noel Curran made a statement about Israel's participation on January 31, stating the organisation was 'aware of the concerns'.\n\nCurran also said it was a 'non-political music event' and is 'not a contest between governments.'\n\nAfter a review by its members, Curran said it was concluded that Israel's public broadcaster 'met all the competition rules for this year.'\n\nOn why Israel is allowed to compete while Russia was banned last year due to the Ukraine conflict, Curran said: Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and, as a non-political media organization, not ours to make.\n\n'In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.'\n\nOn the Eurovision's official website, they have answered FAQ's about Irael's inclusion, including why they were eligible to compete and how the EBU will react if there are protests near the venue in Malm\u00f6, Sweden.\n\nFans have accused Eurovision of refusing to ban Israel from taking part in the 2024 competition because of a haircare brand.\n\nEurovision's presenting partner is Moroccanoil for the fourth year in a row, it's proudly stated on the haircare line's website.\n\nFounded by entrepreneur Carmen Tal, who was born in Chile but is said to have family in Israel, the products are manufactured in Israel, according to fans posting images of the packaging online.\n\nMeanwhile on Companies House, the three officers listed as directors of the company, two in the past and one currently in the active role, are all Israeli.\n\nFollowing the outrage at the EBU's statement, with a new section on 'Why is Israel in the Eurovision Song Contest' posted on the official site's FAQ page, one fan, @slavified, accused: 'the problem w eurovision and israel is that moroccanoil (one of eurovisions biggest sponsors) is an israeli company so unfortunately they're never gonna kick them out cuz they only care about money.'\n\n@EscSocial2023 alleged: 'the @EBU_HQ will not ban Israel from the @Eurovision because their main sponsor is @Moroccanoil - an Israeli company. So never let it be said, that Eurovision is not political, because no matter what the politics are, it all comes down to \u00a3\u00a3\u00a3\u00a3.'\n\n@ElisFeno blasted: 'Also remember: Moroccan Oil is the sponsor of Eurovision! If you wonder why EBU is so keen on keeping Israel in the competition, you must remember EBU values money more than human lives.'\n\n'wait so if eurovision got rid of moroccan oil as a sponsor , it's more likely that \u0456srael would be banned yeah?' @loveruusuvuori also wrote.\n\nThe comments come after Jean Philip De Tender, Deputy Director General of the EBU, said: 'The European Broadcasting Union acknowledges the depth of feeling and the strong opinions that this year's Eurovision Song Contest - set against the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East - has provoked.\n\n'We understand that people will want to engage in debate and express their deeply held views on this matter. We have all been affected by the images, stories and the unquestionable pain suffered by those in Israel and in Gaza.\n\n'However, we wish to address the concerns and discussions surrounding this situation, especially the targeted social media campaigns against some of our participating artists.\n\n'The decision to include any broadcaster, including the Israeli' broadcaster Kan, in the Eurovision Song Contest is the sole responsibility of the EBU's governing bodies and not that of the individual artists. These artists come to Eurovision to share their music, culture, and the universal message of unity through the language of music.'\n\nThe statement stressed the EBU's previous explanations for the inclusion of Israeli broadcaster Kan, saying: 'Constructive debate is a positive consequence of such decisions.\n\n'However, while we strongly support freedom of speech and the right to express opinions in a democratic society, we firmly oppose any form of online abuse, hate speech, or harassment directed at our artists or any individuals associated with the contest. This is unacceptable and totally unfair, given the artists have no role in this decision.'\n\nThe statement ended: 'The EBU is dedicated to providing a safe and supportive environment for all participants, staff, and fans of the Eurovision Song Contest. We will continue to work closely with all stakeholders to promote the values of respect, inclusivity, and understanding, both online and offline.\n\n'We urge everyone to engage in respectful and constructive dialogue and support the artists who are working tirelessly - on what is a music and entertainment show - to share their music with the world.'\n\nHowever, fans have claimed the statement has backfired and is 'making things worse', and have continued to call on the EBU to ban Israel from the competition.\n\nAnd they're not the only ones to boycott. G\u00edsli Marteinn Baldursson is a presenter for Iceland's channel R\u00daV, and has fronted Eurovision commentary for the country's broadcasts from 1995 to 2003, and then from 2016 to 2023.\n\nHowever, he's dropped out from this year's competition, boycotting the 2024 event over Israel's inclusion.\n\nBaldursson, 52, announced his plans to boycott on Instagram, saying [in translation]: 'To answer those who have asked: I will not cover Eurovision this year.\n\n'The reason is Israel's actions in Gaza and the competition's response to it, mainly the lack thereof.\n\n'For me, Eurovision is about atmosphere and joy, and I feel neither in this year's competition.'\n\nBaldursson, who has also hosted his own talk shows, held a short career in politics, as a city representative for the Independence Party in the Reykjavik City Council between 2006 and 2013, after which he returned to television.\n\nHe now fronts a Sunday Morning talk show and a Friday news programme, holding the roles of chief editor and host for both.\n\nIceland will be represented in the upcoming 68th Song Contest by Hera Bjork, with the song Scared of Heights.\n\nEurovision has sparked immense backlash over recent months over including Israel in the Song Contest, with more than 2,000 artists from Iceland, Finland, and the host country Sweden signing open letters asking for Israel to be banned.\n\nProtests in some of those countries have called for Israel to be suspended from the Song Contest after retaliation attacks in Gaza, following Israel's retaliation in Gaza after the Israel-Hamas conflict began on October 7.\n\nDame Helen Mirren, Boy George and Sharon Osbourne are among stars who have signed an open letter supporting the country's inclusion, after it was shared on non-profit body Creative Community For Peace, who campaign against cultural boycotts of Israel.\n\nThere was further controversy over Israel's entry Eden singing October Rain, which contained lyrics that described the situation around the Hamas attack which killed around 1,200 people and took hundreds hostage.\n\nIsrael's public broadcaster Kan later agreed to change the lyrics to the song, and said they had reached out to the songwriters to 'readjust the texts, with full artistic freedom' before being sent to the Eurovision Broadcasting Union for approval.\n\nTheir entry had come under fire after lyrics in the song prompted accusations that they are 'spreading propaganda' and that they contain a political message with reference to the Hamas attacks, with Golan having previously dedicated the track to the Israeli hostages still held in Gaza, saying: 'We won't truly be OK until everyone returns home.'\n\nLyrics in October Rain originally included: 'There's no air left to breathe / No place, no me from day to day.'\n\nMeanwhile, the UK's entry Olly Alexander has responded after being called on to boycott.\n\nThe Years & Years frontman, 33, will represent the UK at the competition in Sweden in May with his song Dizzy.\n\nHowever last year the BBC was urged to drop him as the act after he reportedly endorsed a statement accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza in an open letter condemning the country as having an 'apartheid regime' that 'acts to ethnically cleanse the land.'\n\nAfter calls to boycott, he addressed the controversy in a letter of his own alongside other entrants from Ireland, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Switzerland, Denmark, Lithuania and Finland.\n\nThe statement read: 'We want to begin by acknowledging the privilege of taking part in Eurovision.\n\n'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent. It is important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages.\n\n'We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and islamophobia.'\n\nIt continued: 'We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n'We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nA spokesperson for Eurovision told Metro.co.uk: 'The full list of participating broadcasters in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest was approved by the governing bodies of the European Broadcasting Union and has no connection with, or impact on, any pre-existing partnerships. We do not publicly share commercially sensitive information regarding the sponsors of the event.'\n\nMetro.co.uk has approached Eurovision and Moroccan Oil for comment.\n\nIf you've got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk entertainment team by emailing us celebtips@metro.co.uk, calling 020 3615 2145 or by visiting our Submit Stuff page - we'd love to hear from grand final", "body": "Israeli singer secures spot in Eurovision grand finalJacob Gronholt-PedersenReutersFri, 10 May 2024 5:31AM\n\nSwitzerland and the Netherlands, two of the favourites to win Eurovision 2024, have secured spots in the grand final alongside Israel despite large protests against the country's participation and booing during its performance.\n\nSome 100,000 visitors have gathered in the southern Swedish city of Malmo for the annual kitsch-fest, under heavy police presence as authorities brace for possible unrest.\n\nSwiss rapper and singer Nemo was among those who qualified from the second semi-final on Thursday with the song The Code, as was Joost Klein of the Netherlands with his song Europapa.\n\nEurovision organisers had resisted calls to exclude Israel over its military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' October 7 attack, arguing that the competition is a non-political event.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nIsraeli solo artist Eden Golan, 20, and her song Hurricane qualified on Thursday alongside nine others for Saturday's grand show, which will feature performances from 26 countries.\n\nSome booing was heard from the crowd before, during and after Golan's performance but also applause and Israeli flags waving, according to a Reuters journalist in the auditorium.\n\nMore than 10,000 pro-Palestinian campaigners, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, staged a non-violent protest in the hours ahead of the semi-final, waiving Palestinian flags and shouting \"boycott Israel\".\n\nA smaller group of pro-Israeli supporters, including members of Malmo's Jewish community, also staged a peaceful demonstration in the city, defending Golan and her nation's right to take part in the contest.\n\nHundreds of artists in Sweden and elsewhere had urged that Israel should be blocked from taking part, as did two Belgian government ministers earlier in 2024.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, had earlier requested that Israel tweak its initial lyrics in order to participate, saying they had originally made reference to the October 7 onslaught.\n\nIn a video statement earlier on Thursday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised Golan for her participation.\n\n\"You are not only taking on Eurovision in a proud and very impressive manner, you are also contending successfully with an ugly wave of anti-Semitism - and representing the State of Israel with enormous honour,\" Netanyahu said.\n\nGolan has said she hopes her performance will help unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "8119630729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:34:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:34:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:33:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12651968/eurovision-israel-eden-golan-malmo-palestine-protests/", "title": "Eurovision's Eden Golan told to stay in hotel as 1000s of protestors gather", "body": "ISRAEL'S Eurovision singer Eden Golan has been told to stay in her hotel room after thousands of pro-Palestine protesters gathered in Malmo.\n\nSweden's third largest city was flooded with demonstrators waving Palestinian flags on Thursday to protest Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest this week.\n\nGolan, 20, is due to perform at the second semi-final of the competition later this evening but has been ordered to stay in her hotel room by her country's national security agency Shin Bet.\n\nIt was reported earlier that Shin Bet had warned Golan not to step outside except for performances over fears for her own safety.\n\nMalmo had been anticipating the wave of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and it was feared the young Israeli-Russian singer could find herself at risk.\n\nAs many as 5,000 people have taken to Malmo's streets today, with smoke canisters in the colours of the Palestinian flag being set off and protesters carrying signs displaying images of Gaza victims.\n\nAmongst the large number protesting against Israel's inclusion in Eurovision, however, was climate activist Greta Thunberg.\n\nThe young Swede was pictured wearing a keffiyeh - a black and white shawl commonly used to show support for Palestine - around her body in the centre of the crowd.\n\nSurrounded by a sea of Palestinian flags, she told Reuters news agency: \"Young people are leading the way and showing the world how we should react to this.\"\n\nShe refused to comment on why she had joined the protest, however, only saying it was \"good\" as the march took place.\n\nSome protesters had even brought along their dogs and young children to join in the march, while others held banners displaying anti-Eurovision messages.\n\nOne read \"welcome to Genocide song contest\", while \"stop using Eurovision to whitewash Israeli crimes\" was written on another.\n\nThere was even a banner done in the style of Eurovision with the word \"genocide\" on it, an accusation vigorously denied by Israel amid the country's war with Hamas following the terror group's October 7 attack.\n\nDuring the march, chants of \"Eurovision shame on you! Blood is on your hands too!\" rung out around downtown Malmo.\n\nWhile the sound of police helicopters circling overhead couldn't drown them out, officers on the ground managed to intervene and stop some of the protesters in their tracks.\n\nThere was a significant police presence in the square as Swedish authorities heighten security ahead of possible unrest.\n\nMalmo had already been taken over by approximately 100,000 visitors for the annual kitsch-fest before 5,000 protesters made themselves known.\n\nSecurity fears ahead of the remainder of Eurovision have only increased as a result, with the final taking place on Saturday.\n\nMetal barricades and large concrete blocks have been put up around Malmo Arena, the host venue, where visitors must pass through metal detectors before entering.\n\nBags are being checked and visitors are only allowed to bring in small purses, with organisers concerned political demonstrations could take place in the crowd.\n\nGolan is expected to perform her song Hurricane in tonight's semi final, a piece reworked from an early track October Rain - thought to be a reference to the attack by Hamas.\n\nDuring her rehearsals on Wednesday, however, she was booed and there were reported shouts of \"free Palestine\".\n\nGolan vowed that \"nothing will deter\" her after the performance was interrupted by protesters, vowing that she was \"proud to represent my country\".\n\nOthers in the large crowd did applaud her, though, and the young singer hopes her performance will help to unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she said earlier this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nIsrael's involvement in the competition has been met with fierce criticism due to the country's ongoing war against Hamas inside the Gaza Strip.\n\nHowever, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, has dismissed calls for Israel to be excluded.\n\nThe competition bills itself as a non-political event and can disqualify countries who break that neutrality rules.\n\nThursday's semi-final is due to begin at 7pm (GMT) and will feature contestants from Malta, Albania, Greece, the Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia and Norway.", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-05-350625325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:30:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:30:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:30:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/eurovision-draws-street-protests-calling-israels-ejection-3731629", "title": "Eurovision Draws Street Protests Calling For Israel's Ejection", "body": "Thousands of demonstrators, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, marched through the streets of Sweden's Malmo on Thursday to protest against Israel's participation in Eurovision, an AFP journalist observed.\n\nThis year's Eurovision song contest opened in the southern city on Tuesday, with the grand finale Saturday, but the war in Gaza is looming over the festivities.\n\n\"I am a Eurovision fan and it breaks my heart but I'm boycotting,\" 30-year-old protester Hilda, who did not want to provide her surname, told AFP.\n\n\"I can't have fun knowing that Israel is there participating when all those kids are dying. I think it's just wrong.\"\n\nMore than 10,000 people gathered on Thursday afternoon in Malmo's main square before marching through the city's central pedestrian shopping street, according to police estimates.\n\nAlongside signs that read: \"Liberate Palestine\", banners that said \"EUR legitimises genocide\" and \"colonialism cannot be washed in pink\" could be seen in the crowd.\n\nAbout 50 protesters made it to the front of the Malmo Arena, where the event is taking place, before being dispersed by a heavy police presence. Protesters also entered the Eurovision Village, where spectators can follow the concert on large screens.\n\nIn a different neighbourhood, about 100 counter-protesters gathered under police protection to express their support for Israel.\n\nThe war in Gaza was sparked by Hamas' unprecedented October 7 attack on Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally of Israeli official figures.\n\nMilitants also took about 250 hostages. Israel estimates 128 of them remain in Gaza, including 36 who officials say are dead.\n\nIsrael in response vowed to crush Hamas and launched a military offensive that has killed at least 34,904 people in Gaza, mostly women and children, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's state broadcaster was excluded from the European Broadcasting Union, which oversees Eurovision, in the wake of the war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I feel like if they can remove Russia why can they not do it to Israel?\" said protester Marwo Mustafa.\n\n\"The people are here for Eurovision trying to celebrate. There's nothing to celebrate. It's an ongoing war,\" added 29-year-old Mustafa Mustafa.\n\nIsrael's entry, \"Hurricane\" by singer Eden Golan, will compete in Thursday's semi-final. It has already been partially re-written and given a new title after Eurovision organisers deemed the original version to be too political.\n\nIsrael's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Thursday wished Golan good luck and said she had \"already won\" by enduring the protests that he called a \"horrible wave of anti-Semitism\".\n\nAt the end of March, contestants from nine countries, including Swiss favourite Nemo, called for a lasting ceasefire.\n\nProtester Cecilia Brudell told AFP: \"At six and nine, my children are now at an age where they want to watch Eurovision but this year we are {"uri": "2024-05-350164147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:38:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:38:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:14:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/eurovision-explained-from-abba-to-zorra-as-the-israel-hamas-war-overshadows-the-song-contest/article_7938e187-859f-5d21-8a4b-c8188d1a2ed9.html", "title": "Eurovision explained, from ABBA to Zorra, as the Israel-Hamas war overshadows the song contest", "body": "Scores of musicians, hundreds of journalists and thousands of music fans are gathering in the Swedish city of Malmo, where the Eurovision Song Contest is building towards Saturday's exuberant, glitter-drenched final\n\nMALMO, Sweden (AP) -- Scores of musicians, hundreds of journalists and thousands of music fans have gathered in the Swedish city of Malmo, where the Eurovision Song Contest is building towards Saturday's exuberant, glitter-drenched final.\n\nBut even Eurovision can't escape the world's divisions. Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters are also expected in the city for demonstrations urging a cease-fire in the Gaza war and criticizing Israel's participation in the contest.\n\nHere's a guide to what Eurovision means, how it works and what to watch for:\n\nWHAT IS EUROVISION?\n\nThe short answer: Eurovision is a music competition, in which performers from countries across Europe, and a few beyond it, compete under their national flags with the aim of being crowned continental champion. Think of it as the Olympics of pop music.\n\nThe longer answer is that Eurovision is an extravaganza that melds pop, partying and politics -- a cross between a music festival, an awards show and a meeting of the United Nations Security Council. It's an event full of silly fun, a celebration of music's unifying power, but also a place where politics and regional rivalries play out.\n\nHOW DOES IT WORK?\n\nThirty-seven countries are entered in the contest, which this year is taking place over several days in the Swedish port city of Malmo. The country is hosting after Swedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool, England.\n\nThrough two semifinals, 37 acts are narrowed to the 26 who will compete in Saturday's final in front of thousands of spectators in the Malmo Arena and a global television audience estimated at 180 million.\n\nNations can enter a solo act or a band. They can perform in any genre and language, but the rules state they must sing live and songs must be no more than three minutes long. Staging has grown ever more elaborate, incorporating flashy pyrotechnics and elaborate choreography. This year is particularly strong on topless male dancers.\n\nOnce all the acts have performed, the winner is chosen by a famously complex mix of phone and online voters from around the world and rankings by music-industry juries in each of the Eurovision countries. As the results are announced, countries slide up and down the rankings and tensions build. Ending up with \"nul points,\" or zero, ranks as a national humiliation.\n\nThe musical style of Eurovision has diversified dramatically since the contest was founded in 1956. The early years of crooners and ballads gave way to perky pop - epitomized by perhaps the greatest Eurovision song of all time, ABBA's \"Waterloo,\" which won the contest 50 years ago.\n\nNowadays, Euro-techno and power ballads remain popular, but viewers have also shown a taste for rock, folk-rap and eccentric, unclassifiable songs.\n\nWHO ARE THE FAVORITES?\n\nAccording to bookmakers, a leading contender is Swiss singer Nemo, who is performing a melodic, operatic song titled \"The Code.\" Nemo would be the first performer who identifies as nonbinary to win the contest, which has a huge LGBTQ+ following. The contest had its first transgender winner, Dana International, a quarter century ago.\n\nAnother nonbinary performer generating huge buzz is Ireland's Bambie Thug, whose song \"Doomsday Blue\" is Gothic, intense, over the top and a real crowd-pleaser. They're the only contestant known to have brought a \"scream coach\" to Malmo. Ireland has won Eurovision seven times - a total equaled only by Sweden - but has fared poorly in recent years.\n\nOther acts tipped to do well include operatic Slovenian singer Raiven, Ukrainian rap-pop duo Alyona Alyona and Jerry Heil and Spain's Nebulosa, whose song \"Zorra\" caused a stir because its title can be translated as an anti-female slur.\n\nSo far, the act with the most momentum is Croatian singer Baby Lasagna. His song \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\" is quintessential Eurovision: exuberant, silly, a little emotional and incredibly catchy. It's already a huge fan favorite.\n\nWHY ARE SOME PEOPLE PROTESTING?\n\nEurovision's motto is \"united by music,\" and its organizer, the European Broadcasting Union, strives to keep politics out of the contest. But it often intrudes.\n\nBelarus was expelled from Eurovision in 2021 over its government's clampdown on dissent, and Russia was kicked out in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThis year, there have been calls for Israel to be excluded because of its conduct in its war against Hamas.\n\nIsrael is competing, but was told to change the title of its song, originally called \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' Oct. 7 cross-border attack. It's now called \"Hurricane\" and will be performed by 20-year-old singer Eden Golan at Thursday's semifinal.\n\nPro-Palestinian groups are planning large protests on Thursday and Saturday, and Swedish police are mounting a major security operation, with officers from across the country bolstered by reinforcements from Denmark and Norway.\n\nPalestinian flags hang from some apartment balconies in Malmo but have been banned from the televised event, along with all flags apart from those of competing nations. At the first semifinal's opening act, one performer managed to sneak in a political statement, singing with a Palestinian keffiyeh scarf tied around his wrist.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which organizes Eurovision, said it regretted Swedish singer Eric Saade's decision to \"compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. I can't have fun knowing that Israel is there participating when all those kids are dying. I think it's just wrong,\" 30-year-old protester Hilda, who did not want to provide her surname, told AFP.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's state broadcaster was excluded from the European Broadcasting Union, which oversees Eurovision, in the wake of the war in Ukraine. \"I feel like if they can remove Russia why can they not do it to Israel?\" 29-year-old Margo Mustafa said.\n\n\"The people are here for Eurovision trying to celebrate. There's nothing to celebrate. It's an ongoing war\", she added.\n\nMore than 5,000 people gathered on Thursday afternoon in Malmo's main square, according to an AFP estimate.\n\nAlongside signs that read: \"Liberate Palestine\", banners that said \"EUR legitimises genocide\" and \"colonialism cannot be washed in pink\" could be read in the crowd.\n\nIsrael's entry, \"Hurricane\" by singer Eden Golan, will compete in Thursday's semi-final. It has already been partially re-written and given a new title after Eurovision organisers deemed the original version to be too political.\n\nProtester Cecilia Brudell told AFP: \"At six and nine, my children are now at an age where they want to watch Eurovision but this year we are completely boycotting it\".\n\nSince the beginning of the year, several petitions have demanded Israel's exclusion {"uri": "8118651426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:16:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:16:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:15:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.radiotimes.com/tv/entertainment/sarah-bonnici-eurovision-2024-profile-age-instagram-explained/", "title": "Who is Sarah Bonnici? Meet Malta Eurovision 2024 entry", "body": "They had a pretty lengthy hiatus from the contest between 1975 and 1991, but for the first couple of decades after they returned, they've been a lot more successful.\n\nIn fact, they hold the peculiar record of being the only non-winning country to get four top-three results: third place in 1992 and 1998, and second place in 2002 and 2005.\n\nSince then, the country has struggled to grasp Eurovision glory, but that could all change this year with Malta's 2024 entry.\n\nBut who exactly is Sarah Bonnici, and where might you know her from? Here's everything that you need to know.\n\nSarah Bonnici will be representing Malta at the 68th Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nArguably, no one knows Eurovision better than Sarah Bonnici. She has been mentored from a young age by 1996 Eurovision contestant Miriam Christine, and made her debut in the national selection of 2009's Malta Junior Eurovision Song Contest, where she finished in third place.\n\nThe following year, she was a back-up dancer for the Maltese entry for the 2010 Junior Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nAnd now, she's graduated to the big leagues. She's also participated in the first season of X Factor Malta and has appeared in numerous music festivals across Europe.\n\n\"I don't know if there is a way how to prepare for it,\" Bonnici told Eurovoix. \"You know, I need to work hard to make sure I give the people the best possible opening to the Eurovision.\n\nRead More:\n\n\"It's a great responsibility, obviously, but I'm very honoured to be given that responsibility, I must say.\"\n\nMalta's Eurovision 2024 song is called Loop. Sarah wrote it with Linnea and Joy Deb, who previously wrote the winning song for Eurovision 2015.\n\nOther writers involved with the song include Leire Gotxi Angel, Sebastian Pritchard-James, Kevin Lee and Michael Joe Cini.\n\nMalta did not qualify for the Eurovision final last year. Performed by The Busker, Dance (Our Own Party) came 15th in the first semi-final.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest has faced significant criticism over its decision to allow Israel to compete in this year's competition in light of the current situation in Gaza and the Middle East, with some fans and members of the music industry calling for a boycott of the ceremony.\n\nNoel Curran - director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises Eurovision - has said in a statement: \"We understand the concerns and deeply held views around the current conflict in the Middle East. We can't fail to be moved by the profound suffering of all those caught up in this terrible war.\n\n\"However, the Eurovision Song Contest is a non-political music event and a competition between public service broadcasters who are members of the EBU. It is not a contest between governments.\n\n\"As a member-led organisation, our governing bodies - the Eurovision Song Contest Reference Group and the Executive Board - did review the participants list for the 2024 Contest and agreed that the Israeli public broadcaster KAN met all the competition rules for this year and can participate as it has for the past 50 years.\"\n\nThe artists taking part in this year's contest have also faced backlash for not pulling out of the ceremony, including the UK's act Olly Alexander, who signed a joint statement alongside other entrants explaining they \"do not feel comfortable being silent\".\n\n\"It is important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate and lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages,\" the statement read. \"We stand united against all forms of hate, including anti-Semitism and Islamophobia.\n\n\"We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections. We feel that it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.\"", "source": {"uri": "radiotimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8119549371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:24:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:24:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:24:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/eurovision-2024-thousands-of-pro-palestine-protesters-march-in-malmo-ahead-of-semi-final-13132263", "title": "Eurovision 2024: Thousands of pro-Palestine protesters march in Malmo ahead of semi-final", "body": "By Bethany Minelle, Arts and entertainment reporter in Malmo\n\nThousands of pro-Palestine demonstrators protested in Malmo, Sweden on Thursday against Israel's competing in this year's Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nProtesters waving green, white, black and red Palestinian flags packed the historic Stortorget square near Malmo's 16th-century town hall before a planned march through the city for a rally in a park several miles from the Eurovision venue.\n\nPolice estimated that between 10,000 and 12,000 people took part. Among those in the crowd was Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg.\n\nThe march took place at the same time as Israel's entrant - 20-year-old Eden Golan - was taking part in the final dress rehearsal for the second Eurovision semi-finals, in the Malmo arena.\n\nDuring the march - which included families with young children, and people with dogs and bicycles - smoke canisters in the colours of the Palestinian flag were set off, with some protesters carrying signs displaying images of Gaza civilians who have been injured amid the Hamas-Israel conflict.\n\nThere was also a banner done in the style of Eurovision with the word \"genocide\" on it - an accusation vigorously denied by Israel amid the war with Hamas.\n\nSecurity in Malmo is high, and extra police have been drafted in from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nDuring an earlier rehearsal on Tuesday, Golan was met with boos and cries of \"Free Palestine,\" and an audience member appeared to have a Palestinian flag removed from them in the auditorium.\n\nThe EBU has said only flags that represent countries taking part, and the rainbow flag, can be brought to the event.\n\nThey have said they will remove any other \"flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners being used for the likely purpose of instrumentalising the TV shows\".\n\nThe 20-year-old singer performed her song Hurricane while flanked by five backing dancers and centred around a large wheel-like prop in the centre of the stage.\n\nEarlier lyric changes\n\nThe song has been tweaked three times, after an initial version titled October Rain was ruled too political by the EBU who believed some lyrics referred to the 7 October Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nSome still believe that some lyrics in the current song - including \"Dancin' in the storm... I'm still broken from this hurricane,\" still refer to attacks which killed over 1,000 people and resulted in hundreds of hostages being taken.\n\nIn the run-up to the competition - which is the world's largest live music event - there have been calls for Israel to be banned over their ongoing ground offensive in Gaza.\n\nHowever, the EBU - which says it is an apolitical organisation - has ruled that Israel can take part as they say it has not broken any broadcasting rules.\n\nThe EBU has also condemned harassment and abuse of artists competing in the show and said they form no part of the decision-making process. As it stands no performer has withdrawn from the contest.\n\nMore than 34,000 people have been killed, and over 77,000 have been injured in Gaza since the conflict began, according to Gaza's Hamas-led health ministry.\n\nThe second-semi finals\n\nThe run-through came ahead of the second semi-final this evening, which will choose the final 10 acts to go into the Grand Final.\n\nOther acts taking part in the semi-final tonight include Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, - all of whom called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe UK's act, Olly Alexander, and Ireland's Bambie Thug were also part of the joint statement. Both performed in the first semi-final on Tuesday and will be performing in the final.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been performing since she was nine years old, left Israel when she was six to live in Russia with her family, but returned when she was 18.\n\nShe told ITV News she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\" earlier this week.\n\nThe Grand Final will see 26 countries battle it out on Saturday night.", "source": {"uri": "8119649939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:51:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:51:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:50:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/world/mid-east/thousands-flood-malmo-urging-israels-exclusion-from-eurovision", "title": "Thousands flood Malmo, urging Israel's exclusion from Eurovision", "body": "Thousands of demonstrators, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, rallied on Thursday through the streets of Malmo, the host city of this year's Eurovision, to protest against Israel's participation in the song contest.\n\nThis year's Eurovision opened in the southern Swedish city on Tuesday, with the grand finale to be held Saturday, but Israel's war in Gaza is looming over the festivities.\n\n\"Young people are leading the way and showing the world how we should react to this,\" Thunberg, 21, said, wrapped in a keffiyeh, the traditional scarf that has become a symbol of Palestinian resistance and banned by Eurovision organizers.\n\nMetal barricades and large concrete blocks have been put up around Malmo Arena, which is hosting the competition.\n\nPolice are guarding the venue and visitors need to pass through metal detectors before entering the arena. Bags are being checked and visitors are only allowed to bring in small purses.\n\n\"I am a Eurovision fan and it breaks my heart but I'm boycotting. I can't have fun knowing that Israel is there participating when all those kids are dying. I think it's just wrong,\" 30-year-old protester Hilda, who did not want to provide her surname, told Agence France-Presse (AFP).\n\nIsrael's military offensive in Gaza has killed at least 34,904 people, mostly women and children, according to local health officials.\n\nThe war in Gaza came after Palestinian resistance group Hamas's surprise cross-border attack on Israel on Oct. 7, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, according to an Israeli figures.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's state broadcaster was excluded from the European Broadcasting Union, which oversees Eurovision, in the wake of the war in Ukraine.\n\n\"I feel like if they can remove Russia why can they not do it to Israel?\" 29-year-old Margo Mustafa said.\n\n\"The people are here for Eurovision trying to celebrate. There's nothing to celebrate. It's an ongoing war,\" she added.\n\nMore than 5,000 people gathered on Thursday afternoon in Malmo's main square, according to a police estimate.\n\nAlongside signs that read: \"Liberate Palestine,\" banners that said \"EUR legitimises genocide\" and \"colonialism cannot be washed in pink\" could be read in the crowd.\n\nProtester Kasia Wiatrowska, from Malmo, wore a green T-shirt with the words \"Libre Palestine\" on the back.\n\n\"I do like Eurovision,\" Wiatrowska told Reuters. \"We all love music. But this year music is dividing people, and I don't like that,\" she added.\n\nIsrael's entry, \"Hurricane\" by singer Eden Golan, will compete in Thursday's semi-final. It has already been partially rewritten and given a new title after Eurovision organizers deemed the original version to be too political.\n\nAnother protester, Palestinian Amar, who only gave one name, said: \"I'm here today because I see the hypocrisy and double standards around the world.\"\n\n\"We are against what's happening in Gaza right now. But I also want people to understand that we don't hate Jews,\" he added.\n\n\"At six and nine, my children are now at an age where they want to watch Eurovision but this year we are completely boycotting it,\" protester Cecilia Brudell told AFP.\n\nSince the beginning of the year, several petitions have demanded Israel's exclusion from the 68th edition of the annual music competition.\n\nAt the end of March, contestants from nine countries, including Swiss favorite Nemo, called for a lasting cease-fire.", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Sabah"}, {"uri": "2024-05-350160344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:34:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:34:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:14:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/eurovision-explained-from-abba-to-zorra-as-the-israel-hamas-war-overshadows-the-song-contest/article_623fba50-41b5-599c-83a3-86c744774c6e.html", "title": "Eurovision explained, from ABBA to Zorra, as the Israel-Hamas war overshadows the song contest", "body": "MALMO, Sweden (AP) -- Scores of musicians, hundreds of journalists and thousands of music fans have gathered in the Swedish city of Malmo, where the Eurovision Song Contest is building towards Saturday's exuberant, glitter-drenched final.\n\nBut even Eurovision can't escape the world's divisions. Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters are also expected in the city for demonstrations urging a cease-fire in the Gaza war and criticizing Israel's participation in the contest.\n\nHere's a guide to what Eurovision means, how it works and what to watch for:\n\nWHAT IS EUROVISION?\n\nThe short answer: Eurovision is a music competition, in which performers from countries across Europe, and a few beyond it, compete under their national flags with the aim of being crowned continental champion. Think of it as the Olympics of pop music.\n\nThe longer answer is that Eurovision is an extravaganza that melds pop, partying and politics -- a cross between a music festival, an awards show and a meeting of the United Nations Security Council. It's an event full of silly fun, a celebration of music's unifying power, but also a place where politics and regional rivalries play out.\n\nHOW DOES IT WORK?\n\nThirty-seven countries are entered in the contest, which this year is taking place over several days in the Swedish port city of Malmo. The country is hosting after Swedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool, England.\n\nThrough two semifinals, 37 acts are narrowed to the 26 who will compete in Saturday's final in front of thousands of spectators in the Malmo Arena and a global television audience estimated at 180 million.\n\nNations can enter a solo act or a band. They can perform in any genre and language, but the rules state they must sing live and songs must be no more than three minutes long. Staging has grown ever more elaborate, incorporating flashy pyrotechnics and elaborate choreography. This year is particularly strong on topless male dancers.\n\nOnce all the acts have performed, the winner is chosen by a famously complex mix of phone and online voters from around the world and rankings by music-industry juries in each of the Eurovision countries. As the results are announced, countries slide up and down the rankings and tensions build. Ending up with \"nul points,\" or zero, ranks as a national humiliation.\n\nThe musical style of Eurovision has diversified dramatically since the contest was founded in 1956. The early years of crooners and ballads gave way to perky pop - epitomized by perhaps the greatest Eurovision song of all time, ABBA's \"Waterloo,\" which won the contest 50 years ago.\n\nNowadays, Euro-techno and power ballads remain popular, but viewers have also shown a taste for rock, folk-rap and eccentric, unclassifiable songs.\n\nWHO ARE THE FAVORITES?\n\nAccording to bookmakers, a leading contender is Swiss singer Nemo, who is performing a melodic, operatic song titled \"The Code.\" Nemo would be the first performer who identifies as nonbinary to win the contest, which has a huge LGBTQ+ following. The contest had its first transgender winner, Dana International, a quarter century ago.\n\nAnother nonbinary performer generating huge buzz is Ireland's Bambie Thug, whose song \"Doomsday Blue\" is Gothic, intense, over the top and a real crowd-pleaser. They're the only contestant known to have brought a \"scream coach\" to Malmo. Ireland has won Eurovision seven times - a total equaled only by Sweden - but has fared poorly in recent years.\n\nOther acts tipped to do well include operatic Slovenian singer Raiven, Ukrainian rap-pop duo Alyona Alyona and Jerry Heil and Spain's Nebulosa, whose song \"Zorra\" caused a stir because its title can be translated as an anti-female slur.\n\nSo far, the act with the most momentum is Croatian singer Baby Lasagna. His song \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\" is quintessential Eurovision: exuberant, silly, a little emotional and incredibly catchy. It's already a huge fan favorite.\n\nWHY ARE SOME PEOPLE PROTESTING?\n\nEurovision's motto is \"united by music,\" and its organizer, the European Broadcasting Union, strives to keep politics out of the contest. But it often intrudes.\n\nBelarus was expelled from Eurovision in 2021 over its government's clampdown on dissent, and Russia was kicked out in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThis year, there have been calls for Israel to be excluded because of its conduct in its war against Hamas.\n\nIsrael is competing, but was told to change the title of its song, originally called \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' Oct. 7 cross-border attack. It's now called \"Hurricane\" and will be performed by 20-year-old singer Eden Golan at Thursday's semifinal.\n\nPro-Palestinian groups are planning large protests on Thursday and Saturday, and Swedish police are mounting a major security operation, with officers from across the country bolstered by reinforcements from Denmark and Norway.\n\nPalestinian flags hang from some apartment balconies in Malmo but have been banned from the televised event, along with all flags apart from those of competing nations. At the first semifinal's opening act, one performer managed to sneak in a political statement, singing with a Palestinian keffiyeh scarf tied around his wrist.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which organizes Eurovision, said it regretted Swedish singer Eric Saade's decision to \"compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType":
