{"uri": "2024-05-350271423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:15:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:15:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:48:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.jta.org/2024/05/09/culture/eurovision-and-malmo-brace-for-protests-as-israeli-contestant-eden-golan-takes-the-stage/", "title": "Eurovision and Sweden brace for protests as Israeli contestant Eden Golan takes the stage", "body": "(JTA) -- As the 68th Eurovision Song Contest kicks into full gear, organizers who insist the event is \"non-political\" are fighting a crescendo of protests over Israel's participation amid the ongoing war in Gaza.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which organizes the global competition held in the Swedish city of Malm\u00f6 this year, has tirelessly pushed one slogan: \"United by Music.\" But the group's decision to keep Israel among 37 nations vying for a trophy has instead divided Malm\u00f6, triggered global petitions, caused artists to boycott and generated plans for a flood of street protests.\n\nEurovision launched with its first semifinal on Tuesday. Eden Golan, the 20-year-old singer representing Israel with her song \"Hurricane,\" drew both cheers and boos during a dress rehearsal on Wednesday in advance of the second semifinal on Thursday. Bookmakers have ranked Israel in the top 10 likely victors, which would land Golan among 26 contestants in the final on Saturday.\n\nLocals in Malm\u00f6, which has a longstanding reputation for antisemitism and a record of attacks on Jews by both neo-Nazis and members of the substantial Muslim immigrant minority, unsuccessfully petitioned the city to bar Israel from competing. (The last time the city hosted the contest, in 2013, Jews and non-Jews held a rally after Israeli fans reported harassment.)\n\nNow, Malm\u00f6 is brimming with Swedish police, along with reinforcements from Denmark and Norway, ahead of demonstrations against Israel's participation, including a boat march that took place on Wednesday. Police expect over 20,000 protesters in the small city's streets, outnumbering about 15,000 people holding tickets to gather in the Malm\u00f6 Arena. Outside of Malm\u00f6, Eurovision is expected to draw more than 150 million people to TV screens worldwide.\n\nIsrael's inclusion in the contest sparked international backlash because of its deadly military campaign in Gaza. Over 160,000 people have signed a petition to ban Israel from Eurovision, while 20 artists dropped out from performing in events surrounding the contest. Some protest groups have organized alternative events in Malm\u00f6, such as \"FalastinVision,\" billed as a \"genocide-free song contest\" hosting 15 artists from eight countries -- including the Palestinian territories -- at a live show scheduled for the same time as Eurovision's final.\n\nAmong the artists performing at FalastinVision is Bashar Murad, a Palestinian singer who competed to represent Iceland in Eurovision this year and lost to Hera Bj\u00f6rk.\n\n\"Palestine is blocked from major events around the world -- including Eurovision -- so it's difficult for Palestinian artists to showcase our culture and art globally,\" Murad said in a statement to the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. \"FalastinVision is a beautiful way to address that.\"\n\nBoycotters have accused Eurovision of a double standard for including Israel after excluding Russia from its contest in 2022, one day after Russian troops invaded Ukraine. Noel Curran, head of the EBU, has maintained that Russia was cut off for failing to meet broadcaster guidelines that Israel has met.\n\n\"Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and, as a non-political media organization, not ours to make,\" Curran said in a statement. \"In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.\"\n\nAs part of Eurovision's \"non-political\" guidelines, the contest bars flags and signs other than the national flags of participants and the rainbow pride flag -- which means that Palestinian flags are not allowed in the venue.\n\nOn Tuesday, opening act performer Eric Saade -- a former Swedish contestant of Palestinian origin -- wore a keffiyeh on his wrist, a scarf seen as symbolizing Palestinian solidarity. Saade was reprimanded by the EBU, which said in a statement, \"We regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nThe EBU also cited politicization concerns as its reason for rejecting Golan's initial song entry, titled \"October Rain.\" The song appeared to reference Hamas's Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, which killed about 1,200 people, took more than 250 hostage and triggered Israel's military assault in Gaza. Golan tweaked the song and renamed it \"Hurricane,\" although its lyrics could still be interpreted as a reaction to Oct. 7.\n\nFor many Israelis, the country's participation and success in the contest is a point of pride and an antidote to concerns -- heightened this year amid the war -- that Israel is isolated on the world stage. Israel was accepted into the contest in 1957, its second year, causing Egypt and Syria to exit. It competed for the first time in 1973 and has since won four times, most recently for \"Toy\" by Netta in 2018.\n\nGolan is largely staying out of view during Eurovision week for fear of security threats, skipping most events other than the live shows and rehearsals. In lieu of the contest's opening \"turquoise carpet\" event on Sunday, she went to a local ceremony marking Yom HaShoah, Holocaust Remembrance Day.\n\nFredrik Sieradzki, who heads the Jewish Learning Center in Malm\u00f6, said he welcomed Golan together with the Israeli delegation. Malm\u00f6 is home to a small Jewish community of about 1,000 people, including some parents who have complained of antisemitic incidents at their children's schools since Oct. 7, according to Sieradzki.\n\n\"Eden Golan lit one of the candles. We lit six candles and the seventh one, of course, for the latest victims,\" Sieradzki told JTA, referring to the people killed on Oct. 7. \"It was a very emotional get-together, we felt we were family. When Jews come here, we welcome them.\"\n\nIn an interview with Reuters, Golan avoided criticizing the protests against her performance.\n\n\"It's up to the people what to do,\" she said. \"They have the right to speak their voice, but I'm focusing on my part which is giving the best performance, and on the good, on the good vibes, the good people.\"", "source": {"uri": "jta.org", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-350384757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:01:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:01:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:55:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/97a5c7c4-3596-44ed-9eca-1213cfbcc118", "title": "Eurovision's unity message tested by backlash over Israeli entry", "body": "Eurovision organisers are braced for the most politically charged event in its history as the song contest that celebrates its spirit of inclusion faces protests over Israel's participation.\n\nThe broadcasting union that runs the contest maintains Eurovision is \"a unifying force, bringing together nations and cultures through the power of music\". But though the annual party often carries an undertone of geopolitics -- and has included Israel for half a century -- the involvement of an Israeli contestant this year has sparked a fierce backlash amid the country's offensive in Gaza.\n\nThe Eurovision Village, which will serve the 100,000 fans expected to descend on Sweden's third-largest city of Malm\u00f6 for the event, features heavily armed police and pro-Palestinian protests alongside the typically loud music.\n\nAway from the streets, the tensions have also coloured the competition. Ireland's contestant, nonbinary \"goth gremlin\" Bambie Thug, was the latest artist to evoke the war ahead of Israel's participation in the second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Irish musician, who has already qualified for the final, said on Instagram they had been asked to remove pro-Palestinian body paint from their costume. The writing in a medieval script had included the words \"Free Palestine\" and \"ceasefire\".\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which runs the event, has said it will bar flags and symbols apart from those of participating countries and the LGBT+ community.\n\nBambie Thug said on Thursday: \"My heart and prayers are with the people of Palestine\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009I am anti-war, anti-occupation, anti-oppression and anti-killing of innocent civilians and children!!\"\n\nHundreds of artists in each of the five Nordic countries including Sweden signed separate petitions earlier this year urging Eurovision to ban Israel from the competition, while many of the 26 artists performing in Malm\u00f6 have faced social media abuse for taking part alongside the Israeli act.\n\nBritain's Eurovision artist Olly Alexander was among those who signed a letter in response to calls for a boycott, arguing instead for the \"unifying power of music\".\n\nIsrael's government itself has raised the alarm: the National Security Council urged Israelis not to travel to Malm\u00f6, calling it \"an anti-Israel protest hub\". Israeli media reported that the Shin Bet security service advised Eden Golan, its Eurovision contestant, not to leave her hotel room for anything other than her performances.\n\nShe has already changed the words of the song \"Hurricane\", initially called \"October Rain\", after it was seen to refer to the devastating October 7 attacks by Hamas last year that killed 1,200 people and sparked the war in Gaza. Almost 35,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel's retaliatory offensive.\n\nVideos posted on social media showed Golan being booed by some audience members at a Wednesday dress rehearsal, prompting her to say she was \"proud to represent my country, particularly this year\".\n\nEarlier in the contest, Swedish singer Eric Saade was reprimanded by organisers after he wore a Palestinian keffiyeh scarf around his wrist during a performance.\n\nJean Philip De Tender, deputy director-general of the EBU, said the organiser acknowledged \"the depth of feeling and the strong opinions that this year's Eurovision Song Contest -- set against the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East -- has provoked\".\n\nBut De Tender said online abuse and harassment of artists was \"unacceptable and totally unfair, given the artists have no role\" in deciding which broadcasters take part.\n\nThe EBU represents Europe's broadcasters, including Israeli's Kan, a member since 1957 that has taken part in the song contest since 1973.\n\nEurovision is the latest cultural event to face controversy over the inclusion of Israel, with similar calls for a boycott at the Venice Biennale late last year and clashes over other film and artistic events in Europe.\n\nThe singing competition, which is broadcast to more than 200mn people worldwide, maintains it is \"non-political\" but is no stranger to being used for political motives. Pacts between groups of similarly minded or geographically close nations often ensure that their acts progress, while rivals are handed \"nul points\".\n\nRussia, a former participant, was banned a day after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Ukraine won the contest the following year, an outcome seen as an outpouring of support for the war-torn nation rather than the quality of its musical offering. Another political flashpoint was the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan.\n\nIn 2009, Georgia tried to submit a song \"We Don't Wanna Put In\", widely interpreted as a criticism of Russian President Vladimir Putin. Organisers rejected the song.\n\nAfter Israel was included in the 1970s, Arabic broadcasters refused to show Israeli artists and threatened not to show the contest at all in years when it was hosted by the Jewish state. Israel has won several times, including with transgender singer Dana International in 1998.\n\nLocal dynamics have compounded the pressure this year. Home to one of Sweden's largest immigrant populations, many of them Muslims, Malm\u00f6 has suffered from a reputation for antisemitic incidents. That culminated in videos of cars driving around the city celebrating Hamas's attack on Israel in October, as well as protesters burning an Israeli flag next to Malm\u00f6's synagogue in November.\n\nTensions have risen further since Swedish police allowed a couple -- one of them wrapped in an Israeli flag -- to burn a Koran at the weekend. Sweden's successful bid to join Nato was delayed for more than a year over multiple incidents involving Koran burning by anti-Islam activists.\n\nThe city of Malm\u00f6 apologised this week after cleaning away pro-Palestinian graffiti ahead of the competition, saying it was \"an unfortunate mistake\".\n\nThe contest's organisers have also sought to defuse the situation. EBU boss Noel Curran said it was a \"competition between public service broadcasters who are members of the EBU. It is not a contest between governments.\"\n\nCurran said the EBU had been aware \"of the many voices calling to exclude Israel in the same way as we excluded the Russian broadcaster in 2022\".\n\nBut he added: \"Comparisons between wars and conflicts are complex and difficult and\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009not ours to make. In the case of Russia, the Russian broadcasters themselves were suspended from the EBU due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values.\"", "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/song-contest-trying-avoid-politics-163800818.html", "title": "For a song contest trying to avoid politics, Eurovision 2024 is proving challenging", "body": "\"Boycott Eurovision\" a man shouts into a microphone, \"shame on Eurovision\".\n\nFor a song contest striving to avoid politics, Eurovision 2024 is proving challenging.\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian protestors gathered in Malmo today to demonstrate against Israel's inclusion in the contest as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nRead more: Everything you need to know about this year's show\n\nTonight, Israeli entrant Eden Golan will find out if she's through to the final.\n\nA decision to allow Israel to participate has been contentious, prompting some to boo during Golan's dress rehearsal.\n\nThe outcry follows months of demonstrations and calls for a boycott.\n\nAmong the crowd today a group carries a sign reading \"murder on the dance floor\".\n\n\"I've come because I want to kick out Israel from Eurovision,\" one woman tells me.\n\n\"Some people would argue that you shouldn't mix politics and music, but I feel that is a very narrow view of the world because in the end it is all about politics, it is all about momentum,\" adds Hussein who says he's here because he has Palestinian roots.\n\nGolan says she wants to unite people with music but the ongoing protests add to the tensions surrounding the contest.\n\nThis year's song contest has prompted one of the biggest police operations ever in Sweden.\n\nAgainst the backdrop of two wars and the recent Moscow terror attack, they are not taking any chances.\n\n\"We are aware that Sweden as a country is at a four on a five-point terror-threat scale and we obviously have that with us in our planning,\" Jimmy Modin, a spokesperson for Swedish police, said.\n\n\"We will have a lot of police officers from all over Sweden but also from Norway and Denmark, who will work with us during this week and we will also be flying with our drones.\"\n\nDespite the security presence, some here are nervous.\n\nRead more:\n\nEurovision fans arrive in Sweden\n\nIreland reaches Eurovision final for first time since 2018\n\nEurovision facing controversy\n\nFredrik Sieradzki, a spokesperson for Malmo's Jewish community says antisemitism has been rising since 7 October.\n\nSome fear Jews will be targeted during the contest.\n\n\"People think that something will happen and [some] are getting away from Malmo. Some are very afraid and they will not go out. They won't be at the venues where there will be celebrations and for sure not where there is a big demonstration,\" Mr Sieradzki says.\n\nPolice are hoping their sheer numbers on the streets will {"uri": "8119316085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:31:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/05/09/israel-eurovision-2024-entry-eden-golan-hurricane-song-20806753/", "title": "Everything you need to know about Israel's Eurovision act Eden Golan", "body": "The war in Gaza has led to some opposition to Israel's participation in this year's contest, which became evident during last night's Jury Show, which saw Israel's act booed while performing on stage.\n\nVideos posted on social media showed noisy disapproval and shouts of 'Free Palestine' coming from the crowd.\n\nDespite this, Eden Golan has said in a statement that 'nothing will deter' her, as she prepares for tonight's semi-final.\n\nEden Golan is Israel's Eurovision act for 2024.\n\nShe is a 20-year-old Russian-Israeli singer who began her career at just nine years old, gaining recognition through participating in competitions and winning various awards.\n\nPreviously, Eden was the lead singer of a girl group called Cosmos Girls, and had a string of hits - including Dopamine, Ghost Town, and Let Me Blow Ya Mind - after joining the Israeli record label Session 42 at 18 years old.\n\nEarlier this year, she won the national talent competition HaKokhav HaBa (Rising Star).\n\nIn an interview with Eurovision, Eden revealed that Dana International is her Eurovision hero. The singer said: 'She's a powerful songstress who isn't afraid to break barriers in pursuit of her dreams.'\n\nEden added that she also draws inspiration for her music from Beyonc\u00e9, Ariana Grande, Jessie J, RAYE, Whitney Houston, and Justin Timberlake.\n\nIsrael's Eurovision song for 2024 is called Hurricane.\n\nIt is a rewritten version of October Rain, which sparked controversy because of lyrics including 'There's no air left to breathe,' and 'They were all good children, each one of them,' which were seen as references to the victims of the Hamas attack.\n\nThe song also made reference to 'flowers', which according to the Israel Hayom newspaper is a military code for war fatalities.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which runs Eurovision, describes the contest as a non-political event, and can disqualify contestants who have breached that rule.\n\nAs a result, Israel's public broadcaster, Kan, agreed to amend the lyrics for their entry, at the request of the country's president Isaac Herzog.\n\nThe piano ballad now tells the story of a young woman experiencing a personal crisis, and is among the favourites with bookmakers to win the competition.\n\nThe team behind Israel's entry includes Stav Beger, who co-wrote and produced Toy - the song that led Israel to victory in 2018.\n\n'But on the other hand, I even more so want to represent the country this year, because of its meaning - it has a totally different significance.\n\n'And we can bring everything we're feeling, and everything the country is going through, in those three minutes. To speak through the song to the world.'\n\nWith the news that Eurovision host country Sweden is bracing for anti-Israel protests around the event, it has also been reported by celebrity website Walla Celebs that Eden Golan has faced death threats.\n\nIn a statement, the EBU said: 'While we strongly support freedom of speech and the right to express opinions in a democratic society, we firmly oppose any form of online abuse, hate speech, or harassment directed at our artists or any individuals associated with the contest.'\n\nFollowing the Jury Show, Israeli public broadcaster Kan said that it has issued a complaint to the EBU and to SVT, Sweden's public broadcaster, about the booing at the show as well as political incidents during the first semi-final on Tuesday night.\n\nThe broadcaster also said in a statement: 'Eden stood on the stage during the dress rehearsal with pride and gave an incredible performance. They did not silence her and they will not silence us. See you tomorrow.'\n\nMost bookmakers put Israel as the eighth favourite to win Eurovision 2024, giving Eden Golan odds of around 2%.\n\nEden will have to get through the semi-final first, however. But with Eurovision World placing her as fifth most-likely to qualify, her chances of getting to perform on Saturday night are looking good.\n\nCurrently, Croatia is the favourite to win Eurovision, followed by Switzerland's Nemo as well as Ukraine, Ireland, Italy, France and the Netherlands, which are all favoured over Israel's entry.\n\nAfter Eden Golan was booed during the Jury Show, she released a statement saying she is 'proud to represent' her country.\n\nShe added: 'I am receiving support and love and I am determined to give my best performance tomorrow in the semifinal and nothing will deter me from that goal!'\n\nPreviously speaking to Israeli newspaper Israel Hayom, Eden explained that she is happy just to be taking part in the contest.\n\n'I really want to succeed and believe that we will advance to the Grand Final, but our mere participation is an achievement.'\n\nShe added: 'This year, it takes on a different and greater meaning, standing on that stage and showing that we are here. We went through a hurricane to get to this.'\n\nOn the controversies surrounding Israel's entry, Eden said, 'Some Eurovision fans probably don't like us, and that's something that really surprised me...After I found out, I didn't think 'Why me and why does it fall on me,' but what can be done and how to fix it and make this Eurovision happen. There's no point in dwelling on the 'why,' because that's how it happened, and that's what we have.'\n\nIf you've got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk {"uri": "8119535448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:14:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:14:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:13:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/world/thousands-gather-in-sweden-to-protest-israeli-participation-in-eurovision/3215027", "title": "Thousands gather in Sweden to protest Israeli participation in Eurovision", "body": "Protest comes amid heightened tensions in country surrounding Israel's participation in song competition amid war on Gaza\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators on Thursday took to the streets in the Swedish city of Malmo on the second day of the Eurovision Song Contest in a protest against Israeli participation in the song competition.\n\nThe protest came amid heightened tensions in the country surrounding Israel's participation in the song competition amid Tel Aviv's war on Gaza, in which more than 34,900 Palestinians have been killed, mostly women and children, and tens of thousands injured, with many missing and uncounted for.\n\nPro-Palestinian groups staged large protests in the Eurovision host city with another demonstration planned on Saturday.\n\nSwedish police estimate that over the two days, 100,000 demonstrators will come to the city, according to national broadcaster SVT Nyheter.\n\nToday's protest is expected to bring in tens of thousands of people on the day when the Israeli Eurovision contestant will be performing her song in a semi-final, according to local media reports.\n\nOver 20,000 people from various European countries are also expected to travel to Malmo to protest Israel's participation in the music competition.\n\n\"It is important to shed light on what is happening in Gaza,\" Amanda Nilsson, a protester, was quoted as saying by the SVT.\n\nThe Palestine Network has taken the initiative to organize demonstrations and other cultural activities in the city during Eurovision week, the broadcaster said.\n\nAnother group called the Palestine Group in Malmo is also one of many organizations collaborating to organize two demonstrations in the city.\n\n\"We are planning two large, peaceful demonstrations on May 9 and 11 in Malmo. We hope that many people will come from Denmark to participate,\" Per-Olof Karlsson, one of the organizers, told the broadcaster.\n\nAsked why he felt it was important to stage such a protest, he said: \"Because Israel should be excluded from Eurovision just like they did with Russia.\"\n\nIn solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza and as part of a protest, an alternative music event, called Falastinvision, will be held on the final day of the Eurovision Song Contest on May 11 in Malmo.\n\nMany artists from Sweden and other parts of Europe will participate to show their support for Palestinians.\n\nAuthorities have adopted extra security measures including police with submachine guns and reinforcements from Denmark and Norway.\n\nMalmo, Sweden's third largest city, is home to around 360,000 people spanning 186 nationalities, including a large Palestinian and Muslim population.\n\nLast week, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) decided to prevent contestants, performers, and fans from displaying Palestinian flags and pro-Palestinian symbols during the song contest.\n\nThe EBU said those who try to enter Malmo Arena with a Palestinian flag or a banner containing a political message will be stopped and the flags or banners will be taken away, according to the Goteborgs-Posten newspaper.\n\nIn 2022, Russia was barred from the Eurovision held in Turin, Italy, after neighboring Finland threatened to pull their performer out unless Moscow was banned due to the war between Russia and Ukraine.\n\nThe EBU prevented the country from participating in future competitions.\n\nIceland was fined by the EBU after its Eurovision act Hatari raised Palestinian flags during their appearance on the show held in Israel in 2019.\n\nIn December, the board of the Icelandic Society of Authors and Composers (FTT) publicly called on Iceland's public broadcaster RUV not to take part in the song contest \"unless Israel is denied participation in the competition on the same grounds as Russia in the last competition,\" FTT's General Director Stefan Eiriksson said in a letter sent to RUV.\n\n\"We all have a duty to take a stand against war and the killing of civilians and innocent children,\" Eiriksson said.\n\nHe further emphasized that individuals and states \"always have the choice not to put our name to such things.\"\n\n\"We owe it to those nations that act with force through military might not to share the stage in an event that is always characterized by joy and optimism,\" added Eiriksson.", "source": {"uri": "aa.com.tr", "dataType": "news", I can't have fun knowing that Israel is there participating when all those kids are dying. I think it's just wrong,\" 30-year-old protester Hilda, who did not want to provide her surname, told AFP.The war in Gaza was sparked by Hamas's unprecedented October 7 attack on Israel, which resulted in the deaths of more than 1,170 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally of Israeli official figures.Israel in response vowed to crush Hamas and launched a military offensive that has killed at least 34,904 people in Gaza, mostly women and children, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.Militants also took about 250 hostages. Israel estimates 128 of them remain in Gaza, including 36 who officials say are dead.In 2022, Russia's state broadcaster was excluded from the European Broadcasting Union, which oversees Eurovision, in the wake of the war in Ukraine.\"I feel like if they can remove Russia why can they not do it to Israel?\" 29-year-old Margo Mustafa said.\"The people are here for Eurovision trying to celebrate. There's nothing to celebrate. It's an ongoing war\", she added.More than 5,000 people gathered on Thursday afternoon in Malmo's main square, according to an AFP estimate.Alongside signs that read: \"Liberate Palestine\", banners that said \"EUR legitimises genocide\" and \"colonialism cannot be washed in pink\" could be read in the crowd.Israel's entry, \"Hurricane\" by singer Eden Golan, will compete in Thursday's semi-final. my children are now at an age where they want to watch Eurovision but this year we are completely boycotting it\".Since the beginning of the year, several petitions have demanded Israel's exclusion {"uri": "8119223141", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:31:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:31:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:30:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.thenational.scot/news/24309290.people-boycotting-years-eurovision/", "title": "Why are people planning to boycott this year's Eurovision?", "body": "ISRAEL is to compete in this year's Eurovision Song Contest in a move which has attracted plenty controversy.\n\nEden Golan will be the representative for Israel with her track Hurricane, which was reworked from the original entry October Rain after it was alleged to include references to the October 7 attacks by Hamas.\n\nAfter taking to the stage on Wednesday night during the Jury Show, Golan was booed off the stage as the crowd chanted \"free Palestine\".\n\nSo, why are people boycotting this year's event and what have organisers said?\n\nMany fans have been calling for a ban on Israel taking part in this year's competition amid its bombardment of the Gaza strip.\n\nMore than 34,000 Palestinians have now been killed since October with a further 77,000 people injured.\n\nREAD MORE: Netanyahu is the main obstacle to peace and must be made to go\n\nProtests are set to take place at the semi-final over Israel's involvement while demonstrators also gathered across Scotland last month to put pressure on the BBC not to broadcast the event.\n\nPrior to the 2024 contest, Israel had participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 45 times since its first entry in 1973.\n\nOrganisers behind the event, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), previously banned Russia from competing following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThus far, the EBU has defended its decision to permit Israel to take part and rejected comparisons made with Russia.\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, the deputy director general of the EBU Jean Philip De Tender said: \"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values.\n\n\"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan (the Israeli broadcaster) outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nOrganisers have long banned most flags and signs from the contest - the only exceptions are participants' national flags and the pride flag, meaning Palestinian flags won't be allowed into the venue.\n\nIn April meanwhile, it issued a statement condemning \"abuse or harassment\" directed at participants.\n\n\"The EBU recognises the strong emotions stirred by this year's Eurovision Song Contest and the intense debate sparked by the inclusion of an Israeli entry,\" the statement said.\n\n\"We would like to stress that any decisions regarding participation are the responsibility of the EBU's governing bodies, not the individual artists.\n\nREAD MORE: Boycotting Eurovision is a small but necessary act\n\n\"We are firmly against any form of abuse or harassment directed at participants, online or offline, and are committed to fostering a sae, respectful and inclusive environment.\n\n\"We advocate for constructive dialogue and support for the artists, underlining the Contest's mission to be united by music.\"\n\nHowever, Irish Eurovision finalist Bambie Thug said they were forced to alter a pro-Palestine message calling for a ceasefire.\n\nAnd, Eric Saade, who opened Tuesday night's semi-final, wore a traditional headdress in support of Palestine during his performance.\n\nThe EBU said it \"regrets\" that Saade chose to wear the material and \"chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event\".\n\nOlly Alexander (below) has been selected as this year's representative for the UK.\n\nThe organisation Queers for Palestine circulated a letter, signed thousands, calling for the performer to pull out the show.\n\nHe has described some of the comments he and other participants have faced as \"very extreme\".\n\nAlexander said: \"A lot of the contestants and myself have been having a lot of comments that are like 'You are complicit in a genocide by taking part in Eurovision' which is quite extreme. It's very extreme.\n\n\"I understand where that sentiment is coming from but I think it's not correct. It's an incredibly complicated political situation, one that I'm not qualified to speak on.\n\n\"The backdrop to this is actual immense suffering. It's a humanitarian crisis, a war. It just so happens there's a song contest going on at the same time that I'm a part of.\"", "source": {"uri": "thenational.scot", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8119426140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:51:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:51:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:51:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://theprint.in/entertainment/factbox-eurovision-2024-what-to-expect-as-crowds-gather-amid-anti-israel-protests/2077431/", "title": "Factbox-Eurovision 2024: what to expect, as crowds gather amid anti-Israel protests", "body": "Roughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nThe event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is the Malmo Arena, which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nSeveral protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nProtests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT.\n\nA vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nEden Golan, 20, will represent Israel at this year's Eurovision with the song \"Hurricane\".\n\nIsrael was allowed to compete after agreeing to modify the lyrics of its original song \"October Rain\", which appeared to reference the Oct. 7 Hamas onslaught in Israel.\n\nGolan says she hopes her performance will help unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nIsrael has previously won Eurovision four times, in 1978, 1979, 1998 and 2018.\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high.\n\nVisitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed.\n\nThe results of the two semi-finals are decided by viewers, who can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or the Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nThose in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior to each semi-final and the Grand Final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCroatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final.\n\nWHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nLast year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television, with only seven countries competing - the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice.\n\n(Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson, Louise Breusch Rasmussen and Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen; editing by Sharon Singleton, Christina Fincher, Toby Chopra and Jan Harvey)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@theprint.in", "name": "Reuters", "type": {"uri": "8119477485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:29:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:29:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:28:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/eurovision-irish-fans-protest-israel-malmo-6375404-May2024/", "title": "Group of Irish fans join pro-Gaza protest in Malm\u00f6 demanding Israel's expulsion from Eurovision", "body": "\"It is completely inappropriate for Israel to be given this propaganda platform while they're carrying out a genocide in Gaza,\" one protester said.\n\nA SMALL COHORT of Irish Eurovision fans joined a major protest in Malm\u00f6 this afternoon calling for Israel to be expelled from the song contest as it continues its months-long bombardment of Gaza.\n\nIsrael's participation in Eurovision, which has been a point of contention for pro-Palestine activists for years, has sparked particular anger this year, with the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) facing calls for Israel to be dropped from the competition.\n\nA large protest gathered for speeches at around 3pm this afternoon in a square - Stortorget - near the centre of the port city before moving off.\n\nPeople waved Palestinian flags and carried banners criticising Eurovision, with Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg among the attendees.\n\nAlamy Alamy\n\nThe Journal spoke to a number of demonstrators about what brought them to the protest.\n\nRory Flynn of Eurovision Fans against Genocide was one of a group of four Irish fans at the demonstration.\n\n\"We're a group of Irish Eurovision fans who are opposed to the participation of Israel this year in Eurovision,\" Rory said.\n\nEurovision Fans Against Genocide at the protest this afternoon Daragh Brophy / The Journal Daragh Brophy / The Journal / The Journal\n\n\"Other members are doing a full boycott and [we have] full respect for people who are doing a full boycott. We think it's important to make our voices heard here,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"It is completely inappropriate for Israel to be given this propaganda platform while they're carrying out a genocide in Gaza.\"\n\nSeamus White from Dublin said he is \"disgusted the Eurovision Broadcasting Union is allowing Israel to participate in the Eurovision given the ongoing genovide and oppression of Palestinian people\".\n\nA \"long-time\" fan of Eurovision, he said this week is usually one of \"joy and meeting up with old friends - but this year has been totally, obviously, overshadowed by Israel's participation\".\n\nSeamus has tickets for tonight's semi-final and the Grand Final on Saturday but is not planning to attend this evening due to Israel's involvement and will \"have to make a decision\" about Saturday if Israel's act qualifies.\n\nHe said he attended the first semi-final on Tuesday and that the atmosphere was the \"flattest\" he has ever experienced. \"There's certainly an undertone of unhappiness among some fans at the way things have been handled this year by the EBU.\"\n\nA young woman from Malm\u00f6 who is part of the group Queers for Palestine, who asked not to be named, said it was \"important to show that we support Palestine and that we do not want Israel to participate in Eurovision\".\n\n\"I love Eurovision. This is a dream come true that they come to Malm\u00f6 but I can't go this year because Israel is participating.\"\n\nDaragh Brophy / The Journal Daragh Brophy / The Journal / The Journal\n\nShe said that in addition to local Swedish people at the protest, she was aware of several hundred protesters who had travelled from Norway and Denmark specifically to support the demonstration.\n\nShe refuted the EBU's stance that Eurovision is a non-political contest, citing Russia's expulsion two years ago after its invasion of Ukraine. \"Eurovision is a political contest and it will always be very political.\"\n\n20-year-old singer Eden Golan is due to perform as Israel's entry in the second semi-final at Malm\u00f6 Arena this evening. The current betting odds suggest she is expected to receive enough votes to return for Saturday's Grand Final.\n\nMaking a difference A mix of advertising and supporting contributions helps keep paywalls away from valuable information like this article. {"uri": "8119018357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:15:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:15:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:14:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/factbox-eurovision-2024:-what-to-expect,-as-crowds-gather-amid-anti-israel-protests/77091078", "title": "Factbox-Eurovision 2024: what to expect, as crowds gather amid anti-Israel protests", "body": "MALMO, Sweden (Reuters) -The world's biggest live music event, the Eurovision Song Contest, is taking place in Sweden this week with 37 participating countries.\n\nRoughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nWHEN IS THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2024?\n\nThe event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nWHERE IS EUROVISION BEING HELD?\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is the Malmo Arena, which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nWHAT DEMONSTRATIONS ARE EXPECTED?\n\nSeveral protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nProtests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT.\n\nA vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nWHO IS ISRAEL'S EUROVISION CONTESTANT?\n\nEden Golan, 20, will represent Israel at this year's Eurovision with the song \"Hurricane\".\n\nIsrael was allowed to compete after agreeing to modify the lyrics of its original song \"October Rain\", which appeared to reference the Oct. 7 Hamas onslaught in Israel.\n\nGolan says she hopes her performance will help unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nIsrael has previously won Eurovision four times, in 1978, 1979, 1998 and 2018.\n\nWHAT SECURITY MEASURES HAVE BEEN TAKEN?\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high.\n\nVisitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed.\n\nHOW DOES VOTING WORK?\n\nThe results of the two semi-finals are decided by viewers, who can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or the Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nThose in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nEach country will award points from 1 to 8, 10 and 12.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior to each semi-final and the Grand Final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCroatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final.\n\nWHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE GRAND FINAL?\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nLast year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nHOW TO WATCH IT\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nWHO IS THE FAVOURITE TO WIN EUROVISION?\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nWHO ARE THE PRESENTERS?\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nEUROVISION HISTORY\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television, with only seven countries competing - the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nWHICH COUNTRIES HAVE WON THE MOST EUROVISIONS?\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nWHO WON LAST YEAR?\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice.\n\n(Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson, Louise Breusch Rasmussen and Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen; editing by Sharon Singleton, Christina Fincher, Toby Chopra and Jan Harvey)", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "swi_swissinfo_ch@swissinfo.ch", "name": "Swi {"uri": "8118997917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:04:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:04:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:02:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13399699/Eurovision-2024-expect-crowds-gather-amid-anti-Israel-protests.html", "title": "Eurovision 2024: what to expect, as crowds gather amid anti-Israel...", "body": "MALMO, Sweden, May 9 (Reuters) - The world's biggest live music event, the Eurovision Song Contest, is taking place in Sweden this week with 37 participating countries.\n\nRoughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nWHEN IS THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2024?\n\nThe event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nWHERE IS EUROVISION BEING HELD?\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is the Malmo Arena, which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nWHAT DEMONSTRATIONS ARE EXPECTED?\n\nSeveral protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nProtests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT.\n\nA vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nWHO IS ISRAEL'S EUROVISION CONTESTANT?\n\nEden Golan, 20, will represent Israel at this year's Eurovision with the song \"Hurricane\".\n\nIsrael was allowed to compete after agreeing to modify the lyrics of its original song \"October Rain\", which appeared to reference the Oct. 7 Hamas onslaught in Israel.\n\nGolan says she hopes her performance will help unite people.\n\n\"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\nIsrael has previously won Eurovision four times, in 1978, 1979, 1998 and 2018.\n\nWHAT SECURITY MEASURES HAVE BEEN TAKEN?\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high.\n\nVisitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed.\n\nHOW DOES VOTING WORK?\n\nThe results of the two semi-finals are decided by viewers, who can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or the Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nThose in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nEach country will award points from 1 to 8, 10 and 12.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior to each semi-final and the Grand Final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCroatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final.\n\nWHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE GRAND FINAL?\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nLast year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThere will be 26 acts in total in the final.\n\nWHY THE 'BIG FIVE'?\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nHOW TO WATCH IT\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nWHO IS THE FAVOURITE TO WIN EUROVISION?\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nWHO ARE THE PRESENTERS?\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nEUROVISION HISTORY\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television, with only seven countries competing - the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nWHICH COUNTRIES HAVE WON THE MOST EUROVISIONS?\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nWHO WON LAST YEAR?\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice. {"uri": "8119627532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:31:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:31:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/world/eurovision-explained-look-music-festivals-origins-top-contenders-years-controversy", "title": "Eurovision explained: A look at the music festival's origins, top contenders, and this year's controversy", "body": "Fox News foreign correspondent Trey Yingst brings the latest on the Israel-Hamas war as negotiators arrive in Cairo to discuss a cease-fire.\n\nScores of musicians, hundreds of journalists and thousands of music fans have gathered in the Swedish city of Malmo, where the Eurovision Song Contest is building towards Saturday's exuberant, glitter-drenched final.\n\nBut even Eurovision can't escape the world's divisions. Thousands of anti-Israel protesters are also expected in the city for demonstrations urging a cease-fire in the Gaza war and criticizing Israel's participation in the contest.\n\nHere's a guide to what Eurovision means, how it works and what to watch for:\n\nUKRAINIAN DUO HEADS TO THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST WITH A MESSAGE: WE'RE STILL HERE\n\nThe short answer: Eurovision is a music competition, in which performers from countries across Europe, and a few beyond it, compete under their national flags with the aim of being crowned continental champion. Think of it as the Olympics of pop music.\n\nThe longer answer is that Eurovision is an extravaganza that melds pop, partying and politics -- a cross between a music festival, an awards show and a meeting of the United Nations Security Council. It's an event full of silly fun, a celebration of music's unifying power, but also a place where politics and regional rivalries play out.\n\nThirty-seven countries are entered in the contest, which this year is taking place over several days in the Swedish port city of Malmo. The country is hosting after Swedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool, England.\n\nThrough two semifinals, 37 acts are narrowed to the 26 who will compete in Saturday's final in front of thousands of spectators in the Malmo Arena and a global television audience estimated at 180 million.\n\nNations can enter a solo act or a band. They can perform in any genre and language, but the rules state they must sing live and songs must be no more than three minutes long. Staging has grown ever more elaborate, incorporating flashy pyrotechnics and elaborate choreography. This year is particularly strong on topless male dancers.\n\nOnce all the acts have performed, the winner is chosen by a famously complex mix of phone and online voters from around the world and rankings by music-industry juries in each of the Eurovision countries. As the results are announced, countries slide up and down the rankings and tensions build. Ending up with \"nul points,\" or zero, ranks as a national humiliation.\n\nThe musical style of Eurovision has diversified dramatically since the contest was founded in 1956. The early years of crooners and ballads gave way to perky pop - epitomized by perhaps the greatest Eurovision song of all time, ABBA's \"Waterloo,\" which won the contest 50 years ago.\n\nNowadays, Euro-techno and power ballads remain popular, but viewers have also shown a taste for rock, folk-rap and eccentric, unclassifiable songs.\n\nAccording to bookmakers, a leading contender is Swiss singer Nemo, who is performing a melodic, operatic song titled \"The Code.\" Nemo would be the first performer who identifies as nonbinary to win the contest, which has a huge LGBTQ+ following. The contest had its first transgender winner, Dana International, a quarter century ago.\n\nAnother nonbinary performer generating huge buzz is Ireland's Bambie Thug, whose song \"Doomsday Blue\" is Gothic, intense, over the top and a real crowd-pleaser. They're the only contestant known to have brought a \"scream coach\" to Malmo. Ireland has won Eurovision seven times - a total equaled only by Sweden - but has fared poorly in recent years.\n\nOther acts tipped to do well include operatic Slovenian singer Raiven, Ukrainian rap-pop duo Alyona Alyona and Jerry Heil and Spain's Nebulosa, whose song \"Zorra\" caused a stir because its title can be translated as an anti-female slur.\n\nSo far, the act with the most momentum is Croatian singer Baby Lasagna. His song \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\" is quintessential Eurovision: exuberant, silly, a little emotional and incredibly catchy. It's already a huge fan favorite.\n\nEurovision's motto is \"united by music,\" and its organizer, the European Broadcasting Union, strives to keep politics out of the contest. But it often intrudes.\n\nBelarus was expelled from Eurovision in 2021 over its government's clampdown on dissent, and Russia was kicked out in 2022 after its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThis year, there have been calls for Israel to be excluded because of its conduct in its war against Hamas.\n\nIsrael is competing, but was told to change the title of its song, originally called \"October Rain\" in apparent reference to Hamas' Oct. 7 cross-border attack. It's now called \"Hurricane\" and will be performed by 20-year-old singer Eden Golan at Thursday's semifinal.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nAnti-Israel groups are planning large protests on Thursday and Saturday, and Swedish police are mounting a major security operation, with officers from across the country bolstered by reinforcements from Denmark and Norway.\n\nPalestinian flags hang from some apartment balconies in Malmo but have been banned from the televised event, along with all flags apart from those of competing nations. At the first semifinal's opening act, one performer managed to sneak in a political statement, singing with a Palestinian keffiyeh scarf tied around his wrist.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union, which organizes Eurovision, said it regretted Swedish singer Eric Saade's decision to \"compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"", "source": {"uri": "foxnews.com", "dataType": "news", Protest Israeli Participation In Eurovision", "body": "Protest comes amid heightened tensions in country surrounding Israel\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s participation in song competition amid war on Gaza.\n\nThousands of pro-Palestinian demonstrators on Thursday took to the streets in the Swedish city of Malmo on the second day of the Eurovision Song Contest in a protest against Israeli participation in the song competition.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8The protest came amid heightened tensions in the country surrounding Israel's participation in the song competition amid Tel Aviv's war on Gaza, in which more than 34,900 Palestinians have been killed, mostly women and children, and tens of thousands injured, with many missing and uncounted for.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Pro-Palestinian groups staged large protests in the Eurovision host city with another demonstration planned on Saturday.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Swedish police estimate that over the two days, 100,000 demonstrators will come to the city, according to national broadcaster SVT Nyheter.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Today's protest is expected to bring in tens of thousands of people on the day when the Israeli Eurovision contestant will be performing her song in a semi-final, according to local media reports.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Over 20,000 people from various European countries are also expected to travel to Malmo to protest Israel's participation in the music competition.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8\"It is important to shed light on what is happening in Gaza,\" Amanda Nilsson, a protester, was \"ed as saying by the SVT.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8The Palestine Network has taken the initiative to organize demonstrations and other cultural activities in the city during Eurovision week, the broadcaster said.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Another group called the Palestine Group in Malmo is also one of many organizations collaborating to organize two demonstrations in the city.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8\"We are planning two large, peaceful demonstrations on May 9 and 11 in Malmo. We hope that many people will come from Denmark to participate,\" Per-Olof Karlsson, one of the organizers, told the broadcaster.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Asked why he felt it was important to stage such a protest, he said: \"Because Israel should be excluded from Eurovision just like they did with Russia.\"\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8In solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza and as part of a protest, an alternative music event, called Falastinvision, will be held on the final day of the Eurovision Song Contest on May 11 in Malmo.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Many artists from Sweden and other parts of Europe will participate to show their support for Palestinians.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Authorities have adopted extra security measures including police with submachine guns and reinforcements from Denmark and Norway.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Malmo, Sweden's third largest city, is home to around 360,000 people spanning 186 nationalities, including a large Palestinian and Muslim population.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Last week, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) decided to prevent contestants, performers, and fans from displaying Palestinian flags and pro-Palestinian symbols during the song contest.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8The EBU said those who try to enter Malmo Arena with a Palestinian flag or a banner containing a political message will be stopped and the flags or banners will be taken away, according to the Goteborgs-Posten newspaper.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8In 2022, Russia was barred from the Eurovision held in Turin, Italy, after neighboring Finland threatened to pull their performer out unless Moscow was banned due to the war between Russia and Ukraine.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8The EBU prevented the country from participating in future competitions.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8Iceland was fined by the EBU after its Eurovision act Hatari raised Palestinian flags during their appearance on the show held in Israel in 2019.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8In December, the board of the Icelandic Society of Authors and Composers (FTT) publicly called on Iceland's public broadcaster RUV not to take part in the song contest \"unless Israel is denied participation in the competition on the same grounds as Russia in the last competition,\" FTT's General Director Stefan Eiriksson said in a letter sent to RUV.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8\"We all have a duty to take a stand against war and the killing of civilians and innocent children,\" Eiriksson said.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8He further emphasized that individuals and states \"always have the choice not to put our name to such things.\"\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8\"We owe it to those nations that act with force through military might not to share the stage in an event that is always characterized by joy and optimism,\" added Eiriksson. -", "source": {"uri": Israeli solo artist Eden Golan, 20, and her song 'Hurricane' qualified on Thursday alongside nine others for Saturday's grand show, which will feature performances from 26 countries.\n\nSwitzerland and the Netherlands, two of the favourites to win Eurovision 2024, secured spots in Saturday's grand final alongside Israel despite large protests against the country's participation and booing during its performance. Some 100,000 visitors have gathered in the southern Swedish city of Malmo for the annual kitsch-fest, under heavy police presence as authorities brace for possible unrest.\n\nSwiss rapper and singer Nemo was among those who qualified from the second semi-final on Thursday with the song 'The Code', as was Joost Klein of the Netherlands with his song 'Europapa'. Eurovision organisers had resisted calls to exclude Israel over its military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack, arguing that the competition is a non-political event.\n\nIsraeli solo artist Eden Golan, 20, and her song 'Hurricane' qualified on Thursday alongside nine others for Saturday's grand show, which will feature performances from 26 countries. Some booing was heard from the crowd before, during and after Golan's performance but also applause and Israeli flags waving, according to a Reuters journalist in the auditorium.\n\nMore than 10,000 pro-Palestinian campaigners, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, staged a non-violent protest in the hours ahead of the semi-final, waiving Palestinian flags and shouting \"boycott Israel\". A smaller group of pro-Israeli supporters, including members of Malmo's Jewish community, also staged a peaceful demonstration in the city, defending Golan and her nation's right to take part in the contest.\n\nHundreds of artists in Sweden and elsewhere had urged that Israel should be blocked from taking part, as did two Belgian government ministers earlier this year. The European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, requested earlier this year that Israel tweak its initial lyrics in order to participate, saying they had originally made reference to the Oct. 7 onslaught.\n\nIn a video statement earlier on Thursday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu praised Golan for her participation. \"You are not only taking on Eurovision in a proud and very impressive manner, you are also contending successfully with an ugly wave of antisemitism - and representing the State of Israel with enormous honour,\" Netanyahu said.\n\nGolan has said she hopes her performance will help unite people. \"It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,\" she told Reuters in an interview this week. \"I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8119466455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:20:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:20:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:19:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/eurovision-2024-greta-thunberg-joins-pro-palestine-protests-in-malmo-ahead-of-second-semi-final-13132263", "title": "Eurovision 2024: Greta Thunberg joins pro-Palestine protests in Malmo ahead of second semi-final", "body": "By Bethany Minelle, Arts and entertainment reporter in Malmo\n\nGreta Thunberg has joined pro-Palestine marches in Malmo, Sweden, taking place in protest against Israel competing in this year's Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nThe 21-year-old Swedish activist wore a keffiyeh - a traditional scarf that has become a symbol of support - wrapped around her shoulders at the Stop Israel demonstration, between Stortorget and Molleplatsen in the centre of the city on Thursday.\n\nEarlier this week, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) was forced to apologise after former Swedish contestant Eric Saade, who is reportedly of Palestinian origin, wore a keffiyeh around his wrist while he sang in an earlier rehearsal.\n\nThe march took place at the same time as Israel's entrant - 20-year-old Eden Golan - was taking part in the final dress rehearsal for the second Eurovision semi-finals, in the Malmo arena.\n\nDuring the march - which included families with young children, and people with dogs and bicycles - smoke canisters in the colours of the Palestinian flag were set off, with some protesters carrying signs displaying images of Gaza civilians who have been injured amid the Hamas-Israel conflict.\n\nThere was also a banner done in the style of Eurovision with the word \"genocide\" on it - an accusation vigorously denied by Israel amid the war with Hamas.\n\nSecurity in Malmo is high, and extra police have been drafted in from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nDuring an earlier rehearsal on Tuesday, Golan was met with boos and cries of \"Free Palestine,\" and an audience member appeared to have a Palestinian flag removed from them in the auditorium.\n\nThe EBU has said only flags that represent countries taking part, and the rainbow flag, can be brought to the event.\n\nThey have said they will remove any other \"flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners being used for the likely purpose of instrumentalising the TV shows\".\n\nThe 20-year-old singer performed her song Hurricane while flanked by five backing dancers and centred around a large wheel-like prop in the centre of the stage.\n\nEarlier lyric changes\n\nThe song has been tweaked three times, after an initial version titled October Rain was ruled too political by the EBU who believed some lyrics referred to the 7 October Hamas attacks on Israel.\n\nSome still believe that some lyrics in the current song - including \"Dancin' in the storm... I'm still broken from this hurricane,\" still refer to attacks which killed over 1,000 people and resulted in hundreds of hostages being taken.\n\nIn the run-up to the competition - which is the world's largest live music event - there have been calls for Israel to be banned over their ongoing ground offensive in Gaza.\n\nHowever, the EBU - which says it is an apolitical organisation - has ruled that Israel can take part as they say it has not broken any broadcasting rules.\n\nThe EBU has also condemned harassment and abuse of artists competing in the show and said they form no part of the decision-making process. As it stands no performer has withdrawn from the contest.\n\nMore than 34,000 people have been killed, and over 77,000 have been injured in Gaza since the conflict began, according to Gaza's Hamas-led health ministry.\n\nThe second-semi finals\n\nThe run-through came ahead of the second semi-final this evening, which will choose the final 10 acts to go into the Grand Final.\n\nOther acts taking part in the semi-final tonight include Norway's Gate, San Marino's band Megara, Switzerland's Nemo and Danish entrant Saba, - all of whom called for a ceasefire in Gaza and the \"safe return\" of Israeli hostages in a joint statement in March.\n\nThe UK's act, Olly Alexander, and Ireland's Bambie Thug were also part of the joint statement. Both performed in the first semi-final on Tuesday and will be performing in the final.\n\nThe artists rejected calls from Palestinian groups to boycott the music contest, saying they \"firmly believe in the unifying power of music\".\n\nGolan, who has been performing since she was nine years old, left Israel when she was six to live in Russia with her family, but returned when she was 18.\n\nShe told ITV News she could not have asked \"for a better year to be representing my country\" earlier this week.\n\nThe Grand Final will see 26 countries battle it out on Saturday night.", "source":
